PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Cook moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add:

(a) rejects outright the Government's failure to develop and implement a policy for Australian manufacturing industry and is of the view that, because of the inevitable impact this bill will have on employment, the bill would be more appropriately referred to as the Bounty Legislation (Export of Australian Jobs) Amendment Bill; and
(b) calls on the Government to keep the ships bounty in place until the OECD Shipbuilding Agreement comes into force; and

(c) calls on the Government to develop with industry an industry growth plan for the machine tools and robotics industry sector, the book publishing and printing sector, and the computer industry sector; and
(d) condemns the Government for breaking its own election commitment to maintain the computer bounty until the year 2000."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —When I left off last evening, I was referring to the fact that there are two fronts on which the bounties undoubtedly assist the companies in Queensland that I outlined. Firstly, they provide employment to those companies as small businesses. I think that this is particularly important, because small business is being touted by the government as the generator of employment in our community today. Here we have a government initiative which will undoubtedly impact on the ability of these small businesses to employ.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the bounty enables these companies to be competitive in a particularly cutthroat industry. The removal of the bounty will affect the capacity of these companies to operate. It will affect their employment levels and, undoubtedly, in so doing it will have a flow‐on effect for the community and, in particular, for other industries within the community.

The Industry Commission report was predicated on the continuation of, firstly, a 150 per cent R&D tax concession; secondly, the EMDG and, thirdly, AusIndustry initiatives. These have all been cut and, when the bounty is cut, we will have the computer industry suffering a double whammy. It seems the shipbuilding industry has been accommodated, but now the computer industry seems to have been singled out. My colleague will be moving a suitable motion on the other sectors affected by the government's decision.

The computer bounty has contributed to the growth in this nation's exports. Along with the partnerships for development program, the computer bounty saw information industry exports treble in the last five years. The government should be about supporting small business, not making the success of small business more difficult, if not impossible. I support the amendment which will be moved at a later stage by my colleague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in this second reading debate on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, I particularly want to focus on my own state. Although I probably should have a more global approach, I want to focus on Tasmania because of the very important part of the bill that relates to the ship bounty and, of course, our very famous Tasmanian shipbuilding company, Incat.

SPEECH.PARA: In doing so, I will address the second reading speech of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) in the House of Representatives going to the question of what the government did in pursuit of removing particularly the shipbuilding bounty and also the other bounties that it intended to remove. We have had more moves than those on a chessboard on these particular matters.

Of course, we will hear from the minister's representative in the Senate, Senator Parer, who will tell us, `You people had planned to do the same.' But that is not quite true. It has been stated on a number of occasions now that, in every case, we had a program of reductions in the bounties which were in line with movements in those sorts of protections in overseas countries, particularly with regard to the shipbuilding bounty. The second reading speech in the Senate says:

The success of the shipbuilding industry was reported on by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) in its March 1995 report reviewing the Ships Bounty. One of the recommendations of that report was that it was now time to consider the termination of direct bounty assistance to the industry. In the context of competition from subsidised foreign shipbuilders, the government has therefore decided as a interim measure, to extend the operation of the Ships bounty to 31 December 1997.
The government will review the need for any further extension of the bounty (beyond 31 December 1997) in the second half of 1997—
which we have not got to yet—
The progress towards implementation of the OECD Shipbuilding Agreement (which provides for the cessation of official subsidies by major shipbuilders) is being closely monitored.

The government could not have been monitoring it too closely because it would not have taken the decision that it took to extend the bounty to 31 December 1997. I know that Senator Parer will get up and say that we had a plan that was only going to go to 30 June 1997. Yes; but, as I have said to the minister before, that was on the basis of the OECD agreement proceeding according to its timetable. It was supposed to take effect from January 1996, but clearly it has not. As the minister well knows, and as the department identified in estimates very recently, it is highly unlikely that the OECD agreement will ever be ratified.

There has been a very serious degree of uncertainty in this industry. Not unlike car tariffs, and not unlike the robotics bounty and the computer bounty, the government has had to fall over in light of the pressure—and I have to say logical and commonsense pressure—that has been brought to bear by the industries of this country.
I will turn to the BIE report on which the minister seemed to hang so much of the government's decision. In the foreword of the report, in part, it says:

However, the last 20 years have seen a steady process of declining assistance and international rationalisation of shipyards, recently culminating in the OECD Agreement between the major shipbuilding nations. The Agreement is designed to terminate shipbuilding supports from January 1996—
which I said earlier—
but with some provisions for phase‐out. It will inevitably create some uncertainty in the Australian shipbuilding industry, and the industry will take some time to assess its likely impact . . .

I cannot understand for one minute why the government has not heeded the warnings in this report, let alone why it has tried to use it as justification for taking the steps that it took. Clearly it would not have taken that position had it read this report properly. It simply would not have done it.
On page viii of the report, which is one part of the report I found somewhat unusual, it says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The importance of an economy‐wide approach

SPEECH.PARA: The report makes some important basic points about industry assistance measures, with the following messages for the shipbuilding industry.
First, don't overestimate the value of the bounty to the industry.

I do not know where that came from because further on in the report they say that the bounty was, in fact, the fundamental reason we got a new shipbuilding industry in this country. Even though it may not have been designed for that, it was one of the fundamental factors that brought about a new shipbuilding industry in this country. The report goes on further to state:
To a significant extent it simply compensates the industry for assistance that is provided to other Australian industries.

I really cannot understand the relevance of that. We had an ailing steel shipbuilding industry which was going out the back door. Something had to be done about that so a bounty was introduced. They also say further on in this report that it was, in effect, the very reason we got a new industry. It goes on to state:

BREAK.PARA: Second, it follows that the loss of all or part of the bounty will not hurt as much if other Australian industries are also losing their protection, as they are.

I am at a loss to understand the logic of taking away a bounty that has built an industry and remains in force—although is being phased out—to ensure that the level playing field, which we get to ultimately, remains in place, or at least in part remains in place. Section 5 of the report outlines the main recommendations. This is where you get to the point about how the government could decide that 31 December 1997 was the cut‐off date when they have a good understanding that the OECD agreement, in the first instance, is not likely to be ratified, but, secondly, contained within that was the opportunity for a three‐year phasing out for other countries that have shipbuilding industries and that we compete with. Our industry and the people involved in it have been out there in front, have been doing the work and, yes, have become competitive. I think the industry was happy to see a phasing out of the bounty, but on the basis that certain things happen.
The BIE report finally recognises that. I will read into the record some of the recommendations at section 5.2 of the report. They state in part:
How should assistance to bountiable shipbuilders stand relative to the rest of Australian manufacturing after June 1997? The BIE's recommendations are in four parts.
I will go quickly to subsection 2 of section 5.2, which states:

Australia should seek to join the OECD Agreement unless there are strong reasons to expect that it will be ineffective. In the event that Australia joins the Agreement, the bounty would not be renewed when the current legislation expires in June 1997. There is an outside chance that the bounty will be terminated earlier, that is, if it emerges that there is a strong case for joining the Agreement before June 1997 and continuation of the bounty until June 1997 is not acceptable to existing parties Agreement's phase‐out arrangements.
Subsection 3 states—and I think this is a very important point:

If Australia does not join the Agreement, the average ERA to the bountiable shipbuilders in the period from 1997-98 to year 2000‐1 should be brought into line with the average ERA for manufacturing industry, that is, 5 or 6 per cent.

This is a report, which takes time to get round, which acknowledges that if the OECD agreement is either ineffective or does not come into play then the bounty should continue. This is a March 1995 report. The minister was fully aware of it. Why the government did not understand that particular subsection of the report is beyond me. They are the sorts of things that could have avoided the insecurity that the shipbuilding industry faced as a result of the government's inaction. They are the sorts of things that clearly should have been avoided, but that ultimately led to the backflip on the computer bounty and robotics bounty. The report states further in relation to the BIE's reasons:
Clearly, the BIE's view is that the industry's first priority is to closely examine the opportunity to play on a level field.

Again, there is a very clear indication to the government and the minister in this report that there was a plan, arising out of this report, to phase the bounty out by June 1997. It was always subject to the other conditions coming into effect—the OECD agreement being a major one. Unlike the current government, we at least acknowledged, and had indicated, that should those things not happen we would continue the bounty. It is clear in this report that you would continue it at five to six per cent. The BIE further states in its reasons:

The OECD Agreement reads as a genuine multi‐lateral attempt to eliminate government supports for the shipbuilding industry. If that is how it works in practice, the elimination of support to international competitors will force prices up and thereby compensate—
and this is very important—
the Australian industry for the loss of its bounty.

That is true. I would have thought that would have been fairly easy to understand and yet the government for months maintained a cloud of uncertainty over the shipbuilding industry, I think costing it many opportunities to secure contracts to build further vessels that would have resulted in export earnings for this country and provided more job security, particularly for the Western Australian company and its employees. We finally did do it, but even now we have a half‐baked approach where we say, `It is going to continue through to 30 June 1999 and there will be a review in 1998.'

I do not know why the government has to take that approach and why the government just cannot say that the bounty will continue in line with this report until such times as the circumstances have changed and the OECD agreement has been ratified and takes effect and then allow for the three‐year phase out. It is a fairly simple process. I was somewhat bemused by some of the things in the BIE report and the logic they applied, but at least when it came down to it they put some fairly basic steps to follow in there, yet the government cannot follow them.

I will go to a letter which in part formed a submission to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee which considered this legislation. The letter is from the Tasmanian Liberal Premier. I do not agree with too much of what he says but on this occasion I do sympathise with the views in the letter he forwarded to Senator Ferguson. The letter reads in part:
Quite obviously the first jurisdiction to remove barriers, while their competition continues to have barrier protection, will be at a distinct disadvantage on the world market.

While the Commonwealth's need to explore all measures to improve its budget position is acknowledged, the fact is that Australian companies have relied upon this bounty in negotiating contracts which were agreed prior to the knowledge that the ship building bounty will cease on 30 June 1997. With vessels now under construction, companies now face the unreasonable position of having to absorb the full value of the lost bounty into their costs of production.

The Tasmanian Government strongly supports the retention of the bounty at its current rate of 5% until such time as industry assistance in overseas countries, such as the European shipbuilding nations, is removed.
The Premier of Tasmania could get it right; he had a reasonable understanding. He continued:
The Australian shipbuilding industry operates against heavily subsidised competition, particularly from Europe which receives a subsidy of at least 9%.

That is right; we know that. If poor old Tony Rundle could get that right, then I would have thought it would have been a fairly simple thing for the government to follow through. But, no, it could not do that. It threw this industry into a state of confusion, along with the other industry.

The other very significant industry is that to which the book bounty applies. I would have thought the efforts of this government ought to be on import replacement. Why would we want to kill off our own industries? We have a population of a bit over 18 million and we want to lead the world, to lead the charge in removing assistance to some of our industries.

The government can take account of the budget argument, the fiscal problems that we may have. But, at the end of the day, they will be twice as bad if we continue to throw people out of work. In a lot of other areas we have no industry strategy whatsoever coming from the government. It is about time—particularly from an employment point of view—that the government gave some serious thought to industry strategy and industry development.

I have stood in this place on a number of occasions and spoken about the forest industry—which has a zip strategy. It will not be too long before this industry goes further down the chute, and we will see more and more of the jobs in that industry being shipped off overseas.

I call on the government to at least take some steps to provide certainty for industries that have bounty assistance and some real plans for our industries, not the current flip-flop approach we have had with the industries with which we have been dealing—particularly the car industry most recently. I urge senators to support the amendment moved by Senator Cook, because it will make this legislation much better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The original decisions made by the government when it decided to abolish the books, machine tools and robotics, shipbuilding and computer bounties were the decisions of a naive and inexperienced government. They were so poorly considered that the government has actually had to reverse its position on a number of them. This very fact sums up what everyone knows and has been saying ever since the government launched an all‐out assault on industry assistance mecha nisms, without any concern for the long‐term implications. This government has had no industry policy. It still does not have an industry policy, but at least it now is aware of this, and has undertaken the Mortimer review in the hope of rectifying this serious deficiency. At least the government is not making errors of judgment on the scale it made in its first year in office and at least it has had the courage to reverse some of its decisions, if not all.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not forget that, when the government made its decision to abolish the bounties, the industry minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) defended the position. Maybe the industry minister defended the position because the Treasurer made him—because since he certainly has shown a different mettle. The government said that the decisions had been well considered—they were not—and told us that they would not detrimentally affect employment or manufacturing activity—and they did. The government has recognised they were not good decisions and, therefore, has reversed some of them, for which we thank it.

Why has the government decided to extend, rather than cut short, the shipbuilding bounty? Why has it reversed its decision to phase out the machine tools and robotics bounty ahead of schedule? The answer is because the decisions were poor and because they have affected investment, jobs, growth and exports. As we now know, the government's dithering about has cost substantial contracts, particularly to the shipbuilders. But that, I am afraid, has happened, and we have to wear that. The decisions to prematurely remove the computer and books bounties were also poor decisions. Unfortunately, these industries have not benefited from the government's slow awakening.

The government had only one objective when it set out on its assault on bounties and other industry and export assistance measures: short‐term revenue savings. There was no cost benefit analysis, no sensitivity analysis, no medium‐ to long‐term assessment of the effects on the economy, on jobs and on the communities from its assault on these industry assistance measures.

Focusing only on government expenditure levels in such a short-sighted manner will not safeguard Australia's long‐term prosperity nor will it generate, let alone retain, jobs. Abolishing these bounties will, in the opinion of the Australian Democrats, abolish jobs. It will, in the opinion of the Australian Democrats, diminish our manufacturing sector. And those are views shared by the manufacturing sector.

All of us in this chamber know that the manufacturing sector is stressed and it needs assistance in the areas of jobs, investment, growth and exports. What occurs when critical support measures are removed, regardless of the broader economic impact and regardless of the specific impacts on the industries in question, are not just the measurable effects but the immeasurable effects of a lack of confidence, of insecurity and of poor planning decisions resulting from those effects.

The government has argued that these bounties can be abolished because they are only a minor determinant of profitability and competitiveness for these industries, and that manufacturing activity would therefore continue unaffected. But cost benefit analyses of the impacts on jobs, investment, growth and competitiveness of abolishing these bounties were not undertaken. In other words, those were assertions; they were not empirically or objectively based.

By contrast, industry representatives—even if we accept their clear self‐interest in so arguing—have provided and presented evidence showing that bounties have enabled domestic manufacturers to expand market share and, by adding to revenue, have fostered industry investment and development. This has been crucial to supporting employment and improving competitiveness. Moreover, this was confirmed by the Industry Commission.

If the government thinks otherwise, then it should table a detailed empirical objective analysis showing why. Neither in an estimates process nor in hearings nor in any sector has the government been able to respond on that basis. The government should respond on that basis, because bounties are part of an industry assistance package which affects very considerable industry sectors.

In South Australia, for example, the sectors covered by the four bounties—the books bounty is important within that—account for approximately eight per cent of total employment, and more than eight per cent of value added in the manufacturing sector. Moreover, the machine tools and robotics industries, the shipbuilding industry and the computer hardware industry are the types of growth industries that we need to encourage as we move towards the 21st century. They are research and development intensive. Research and development constitutes a significant percentage of turnover compared to manufacturing generally. This means that they employ high skilled, high wage labour, and are heavily export oriented.

It is not just the impact of the bounty cuts that needs to be considered. The impact of the removal of the bounty needs to be assessed in tandem with the cuts the government has made to research and export assistance programs. The 150 per cent tax concession for R&D was effectively halved by reducing the rate to 125 per cent, and the export market development grants program was severely curtailed, as was the DIFF program. These programs were highly valued by these research and export intensive industries. Coupled with the impact of the abolition of bounty assistance, the end result will be to weaken our manufacturing base and to destroy jobs, not create jobs.

But this did not figure in the government's and, particularly, in the Treasurer's consideration. He just has a one-eyed kind of accountant's view of balancing the books. That is very important, but it is not the only responsibility of this government. Nor did it occur to the government to consult fully at the time with the industries concerned. In fact, the decisions affecting the book and machine tools and robotics manufacturers were taken prior to the completion of Productivity Commission inquiries into each of these industries. The government's decisions actually go further in winding back assistance than rec ommended by the Industry Commission in draft reports, which were publicly released at that time. The draft reports for both of those industries, not surprisingly, recommended that these bounties be phased out on their scheduled termination date. I say `not surprisingly' because the Industry Commission has a reputation for ideology.

The Industry Commission did not, however, recommend that they be abolished beforehand, as the government attempted. That is the second major problem. Not only did they not do the analysis and assess the impact on the economy but they were going to break our contractual committed word. Breach of contract, as we found in the DIFF situation and our foreign affairs bungling, is a very bad thing for government to have laid on it. The fact is that there is a strong case to be made that bounties with a known and accepted expiry date represent contractual obligations between government and the industries concerned. These contracts should not be broken.

It is interesting to note that, during the recent debates over the assistance for the car industry, the government said it would not make a decision until the final Productivity Commission report had been completed and that they would not release the final report until they had made a decision on future assistance for the car industry. The Treasurer insisted this was conventional procedure.

If this is conventional procedure, then why did the government treat the machine tools and robotics manufacturers and the book industry with such contempt? Why did they bother to put them through the efforts of making submissions and supplementary submissions and appearing before public hearings if the whole exercise was to have no bearing on the government's decision, which was based on other considerations? Why have the government still not released the final reports? The final draft of the book industry report was apparently completed in October last year. The machine tools and robotics bounties final report was completed in August last year—nearly a year ago.

The answer is obvious to us. These industries do not carry as much weight as car manufacturers in this government's view. You are perfectly at liberty to prioritise industries and manufacturers as you see fit, but ignoring these people because they do not carry as much electoral weight is not a good reason to do so.

An industry composed of a large number of small to medium sized firms apparently does not rank as highly, as worthy or as important as an industry composed of a handful of global giants. But the fact is that both the global giants and those small and medium sized firms are integral to our social and economic wellbeing.

The book industry has been the recipient of particularly poor treatment. Not only are the government still seeking to abolish their bounty ahead of schedule but they are prepared to leave incentives weighted in favour of offshore, rather than domestic, production. That again is an area of bias which the government needs to correct. Stop pushing offshore production ahead of domestic production. The government are prepared to advantage imports over Australian manufacturing.

Under the Florence agreement, fully imported books are brought in duty free while inputs such as paper enjoy a five per cent tariff. This effectively leaves book producers with a negative rate of assistance and, unlike the computer and shipbuilding industries whose bounties are also at risk, no alternative or compensatory assistance measures have been considered. It is not surprising, therefore, that preliminary results of a recent survey by the Australian Publishers Association indicate that printing in Australia is declining rapidly, whereas offshore printing is rapidly increasing. I cannot see why that is in the interests of your government or this country.

The Democrats believe that, as a minimum, the book bounty should be retained at an equivalent rate to the general tariff rate, at least until such time as compensatory measures are put in place to offset the negative assistance to an effective rate of zero. We should not be giving up any advantage for our industries unless there is an equivalent international competitive advantage for us.

The shipbuilding industry was the most fortunate of the four being considered, but they were only fortunate because of an unusual alliance of strong forces which pushed forward the change. Those forces included the political forces of the Democrats and the Labor Party, of Premier Court in Western Australia and of a very vigorous lobbying effort by the industry concerned.

To date, the shipbuilding industry has performed extremely well, with almost 90 per cent of production being exported. Its strengths lie in niche areas, such as high speed aluminium ferries—where Australian builders supply about one-third of total world demand—and defence projects such as submarines and frigates. Enjoying one-third of total world demand as a market share was the very area that the government was going to put at risk. How can you claim to be strong and capable economic managers when you take such a risk with such an important niche industry?

While Australian shipbuilders are highly export oriented, unfortunately, they compete in an environment of high subsidies by foreign governments. Fortunately, the government undertook a complete policy reversal, and Minister Moore is to be congratulated for eventually coming to that view. This bill initially sought to prematurely abolish the shipbuilding bounty. Now it actually extends it six months. I hope they will continue to review it during those six months.

The decision to extend their bounty is welcome news. It required a great deal of lobbying before the government was convinced to move in the right direction—in the direction which will safeguard jobs, investment, exports and growth in that industry. Unfortunately, the government is still proposing to phase it out prior to the European Union phasing out assistance measures for their shipbuilders.

We cannot continue on that basis. No giving up Australian advantage and no giving up Australian competitiveness until there is an equivalent international commitment. That is all. It is a very simple mantra you need to adopt—you will not give up anything for Australia unless our international competitors give it up too. That is all; it is very simple.

BREAK.PARA: The importance of ensuring our manufacturers are on as level a playing field as possible with their key international competitors is understood in theory by the government, but has not yet been fully accepted by all elements of the government, particularly those who belong to the small, elitist and fundamentalist school of thought characterised by the H.R. Nicholls Society adherents. For this reason, the Democrats will seek to extend this bounty to ensure we give equal support to our industry as that provided by the European Union until such time as the European Union changes its assistance rates. If we fail in this attempt, we will support the government's extension.

The government's policy reversal with respect to the machine tools and robotics bounty is also welcome. The bounty will no longer be prematurely abolished and retrospective impacts will be avoided. This was of concern because a number of companies would have been placed under considerable burden had they been forced to pay back bounty payments.

But the fact is that the bounty is being abolished. This industry is fundamental to the entire manufacturing sector. It supplies leading-edge technologies to many other sectors, including and especially, I think, the car industry sector, and it is an important source of innovation and skills. In other words, it is an industry of the future which deserves nurturing.

The bounty has been instrumental in the growth of the industry. It has had 20 per cent per annum growth in exports over the last 10 years. That is not something we should put at risk. Allowing the bounty to lapse without any alternative assistance mechanisms means the end of a successful industry program which was critical to fostering the growth of firms in this sector.

In conclusion, the policy reversals over shipbuilding and machine tools and robotics are welcome but they are not enough. They are only piecemeal measures undertaken in isolation. The government must go much further—and we recognise it does intend to do so—in refining its approach to industry policy. In partnership with each of these industry sectors, the government must urgently formulate industry development plans by sector.

Critical issues affecting the growth of these industries must be addressed and appropriate support measures must be implemented to ensure domestic manufacturers are not at a disadvantage with their international competitors. Failure to do so will mean failure to deliver on jobs. It will attack jobs, not create jobs. Unemployment is, Minister, the most crucial issue of our time and of your government. Solutions are needed and industry policy is, and must be, one of the primary solutions.

Minister, the first 1½ years of your government has seen the loss of tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs and the loss of tens of thousands of jobs in the economy overall. It is not something you are happy with—it is not something anyone is happy with—but we have in this bill one small element in recreating a situation in which we can create jobs and improve the job situation, not destroy and attack them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Madam President, for those of us who have been involved in the fight to save Australia's shipbuilding industry, the news that the government will extend the shipbuilding bounty to cover ships contracted for and completed within three years is welcome.

But this concession, however welcome, does not fully solve the problem it was meant to address. Several months ago in Hobart over one thousand ship building workers signed an open letter which was been sent to every federal politician. In that letter they asked us to represent them and use our votes to extend the ship building bounty. Not indefinitely. Just until they can compete fairly with their european competitors the extension of the bounty only addresses some of their concerns.

We have seen the government abolish the bounty, change their minds and extend it to June this year. Think again and change the cutoff date to December. Now the three year completion clause has been hastily added.
I recommend a tried and true labor method, `consult with industry before you make decisions affecting them so profoundly.
This continuous fiddling with the shipbuilding bounty provisions has given industry no certainty and could not come at a worse time for Tasmania.
Tasmania is not in good shape.

The lack of strategic direction and sound industry policy on the part of two successive state liberal governments and federal government bludgeoning of the state through budgetary and other decisions have cost the state thousands of jobs.

Tasmania has lost 6400 full time jobs in the past fourteen months. In terms of total employment including part-time and casual work, the jobs loss over the same period is 7200. This pattern of job losses looks to continue.

In the past months, Tasmanians have opened their newspapers to see headlines like: "Tassie reels as jobs woe grows." (Mercury Monday 5 May) and "state's job level worst since 1984" (examiner 13 June) `Tasmania's largest textile manufacturer Coats Patons of Launceston announced it was closing in July, throwing one hundred and seventy-five people out of work.
The state's biggest insurer TGIO sacked twenty-five workers—fifteen in Hobart I and ten in Launceston—giving them just one day's notice.
Stanley tools has closed it doors with the loss of 26 jobs. Interline roof manufacturers has closed with the loss of 50 jobs. ACI glass of Hobart has closed with the loss of a 140 jobs.

I don't know how many of you saw the television coverage of the closure. The sight of scores of workers leaving their place of work for the last time, knowing there are no jobs out there, was sickening.
Enough is enough.

A recent yellow pages survey found that 20 per cent of small business in Tasmania identified a lack of markets as the most important barrier to investment.This was backed up by a similar finding in the recent Tasmanian chamber of commerce and industry survey of small business.
The government's lack of industry policy means that industry remains deeply reluctant to expand and provide new jobs.
Tasmania is also vulnerable due to the narrowness of its industrial base. Seven companies employ approximately ten thousand Tasmanian's.
A threat by any one of these employers to leave Tasmania has in the past caused political instability and a loss of confidence in the overall Tasmanian economy.
Tasmania's unemployment rate remains the worst in the nation at around 10.8 per cent, 2 per cent worse than the rest of Australia.

Had not a significant number of people stopped seeking work- Tasmania's unemployment figure would have been much worse. The participation rate dropped to 59 per cent its lowest level since October 1987. Tasmanians are opting out of looking for work and this government offers them no hope the recent budget held no joy for Tasmania's jobseekers.
The increasingly grave situation in Tasmania looks like getting worse when national forecasts are taken into consideration.

Conservative economists are now predicting a significant rise in national unemployment in the coming months. Annex's Saul Eastlake predicts a national rate of 9 per cent by June 1997. Where will the Tasmanian rate be? At eleven percent? At twelve percent? The current Tasmanian government has no answer to the federal government's attack on our state.

Liberal Senators and Members of the House of Representatives have done nothing. Pleas for special treatment have fallen on the deaf ears of both the Prime Minister and Treasurer. The latest budget confirms they haven't been listening.
Tasmania has got specific needs. Federal decisions which affect Tasmania should be preceded by a full study of the economic and social impact of those decisions on the state.
And yet the federal government continues to make decisions on the run which cost Tasmanian jobs.
The first Howard budget produced savage cuts to community services and public programs and has further added to the severe strain on our economy. The second has continued that trend.

The government's original decision not to continue the shipbuilding bounty put an incredible strain on one of our most important industries and demonstrated the federal governments lack of a coherent industry policy.
It is simply not good enough for the Prime Minister to describe industry policy as "a pretty limited debate" as he did on ABC radio in December last year.
Australian workers and industry deserve better.

However, the Prime Minister's statement demonstrates clearly that his government has no vision for the Australian manufacturing industry and that industry policy is not a priority for either the Prime Minister or his government.
The current do nothing approach of the federal government which leaves industry to the vagaries of the market approach demonstrates a single minded adherence to the free market philosophy.

Sadly this leaves industry without policy guidelines and puts ever greater pressure on the social fabric. This will inevitably lead to greater unemployment. This is particularly true for Tasmania as the unemployment trend so clearly demonstrates.
The model for Australian industry development is not to be found in the failed models of the United Kingdom or the United States of America.
We need a planned economy.

We need a government which responds rapidly to ensure continuing growth. Government needs to unite with industry, educational institutions, and in Australia's case the trade unions, to forge a new model for industrial co-operation and development. The goal of such an alliance should be to provide industry with a suitable mix of industry incentives, an educated workforce and a workforce which is included not excluded from the process of decision making.

The divide and conquer advice and policies of the free marketeers who advocate more privatisation, corporatisation, deregulation, diversification, and the dismantling of the public sector is the absolute opposite of what we need.

The federal government must recognise the need for a strong and workable industry policy. Alan Hanberg of the Australian chamber of manufacturers describes the Australian people as frightened." Tasmanians share that fear.

Hanberg has also noted that employment will not grow while the government continues to inhibit industry by cutting job training programmes, slashing development grants, and placing taxes on imported equipment essential for real growth in the manufacturing sector.

Those who do not have work must know that the first priority of the government's industry policy is the maintenance and creation of viable and sustainable jobs.

Tasmania has suffered large cuts to federal government programmes which have hit the state's ability to export. Export businesses need security if they are to grow and expand their markets.

Not only has the industry expanded enormously in the past ten years but it has a great future. The increasing demand for the development of high speed freight guarantees a future market for high speed vessels.
This is the very market that Incat, the ship building industry in Tasmania, is poised to dominate. I would like to describe the contribution Incat makes to the Tasmanian economy.

Incat's contribution to that figure was one hundred and eighty million dollars or ten point seven percent. Estimated export figures for 1997 put Incat at two hundred and sixty seven million or fifteen percent of the total.
Fifteen percent of the export effort of the state.

In 1988, Incat had thirty-one employees. As at the twentieth of February, Incat had nine hundred and twenty seven permanent employees, one hundred and twenty- one apprentices, seventeen-job skill workers and four casual staff.

This company employs point seven six percent of the state's full time work force, four percent of its apprentices and seven point four percent of its trainees. These are the industries of the clever country: high tech, using highly skilled workers and generating employment and considerable income.

We have a trade deficit of $6 billion a year on the importation of technology for this industry. It is forecast to go to a trade deficit of $20 billion a year by the end of the century—with the bounty. The bounty provides some comfort to Australian manufacturers of computer hardware and component parts.

The minister, in his reply on the second reading debate, said, `But everyone knows that Australia is good at software. Let's go to our comparative advantage; let's build software. Let's not try to develop a Silicon Valley in Australia; that's been done and the Asians are better at manufacturing than we are.' The truth is that Australia is damned good at manufacturing and is an exporter of manufactured computer hardware. That is the truth of the matter, and let the international market decide who is best at it. We are very good at it and we have an international market presence because of that.

The bounty is a small bounty that enables us to win in those circumstances. Let us not run away with the idea that the Asians, the Europeans and the Americans do not protect and help their industries. Of course they do. Of course they do, because they regard this as a strategic industry sector. Computer and information technology is enabling technology. It enables the work of all other businesses to be done more efficiently and more competently. It is exploding in demand and it is exploding in competence—and it is in reach. Australia is saying, very interestingly, `We'll come out of this industry now; we're not interested in it.'

All of the studies about Silicon Valley show that you need a manufacturing sector, the hardware sector, to be alongside the scientists and to be alongside the software writers, so that you have all the elements of the industry interacting with one another and stimulating growth, imagination and new ideas in the creation of technology, one off another. We have a world leading software industry in Australia. That is true. We have a competitive, still growing, but relatively smaller, hardware industry in Australia.

If you kill the hardware sector, our software writers have to interact with hardware being developed by other companies offshore. They have to go overseas to understand the newest applications of technology and to work their software around that. While you have it here, they can work it around what is in Australia. You need both sections of the industry to be in balance, because if you take one away, the other will wither. That is the story of Silicon Valley. That is the story of where computer manufacture has grown up elsewhere in the world. We are a small country in the world. We have to be smarter, brighter, quicker and better than other countries—just to be equal.

The bounty is a reason why a number of major companies invest in Australian computer manufacturing. An example is IBM, one of the world's biggest companies. It has been going through a massive restructuring because it has been in financial loss for a number of years. It is just coming out of that. During the period in which it was closing down plants all around the world, it kept open its plant in Wangaratta, and did so because we were competitive. The bounty is the thing that has made the difference in that plant being here.

I know, in my experience as industry minister, in 1995, there was some consideration that if the bounty was not continued through to the year 2000, the international corporate plan of a company like IBM, where they were in financial loss and consolidating their outlets and manufacturing plants, and streamlining their operation—cutting off their dead wood—would have aggregated those plants back to a central manufacturing establishment. That would have been in Austin, Texas. So out of Wangaratta and over to Austin would be the effect of not having a bounty in this industry.

That is jobs in country Victoria. These are intelligent jobs. These are good jobs. These are jobs that give Australia a place in world information technology development too. Why would we shoot ourselves—not in the foot, but in the head, in this case. Why would we remove the concession and break a solemn election promise that the government made in the case of this industry?

I refer the Senate to page 9 of the Senate economics committee's report on bounties, to the points that the computer companies made about the negative effect of the removal of the bounty on them. There is a whole series of bullet points there, but it is too long for me to recite.

The fundamental point in opposing this is: the government would, if this is carried, explicitly break their election undertaking. Companies had taken solace and encouragement from the fact that the government had said that the bounty would continue to the end of the century. They have cast their corporate development plans, their investment plans, their employment plans, and their research and development and new product development plans accordingly. To remove the bounty now would be to throw all of that into the trash can and to disrupt their operations.

It would also be to give Australia a reputation of being capricious, that you cannot rely on the government in Australia to be consistent about what it says. From an international investment point of view, that is disastrous. This is an industry in which demand is not just growing, but exploding, and Australia needs to keep itself in this game if it is going to be a relevant 21st century economy. To remove this bounty is to go against all of those things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill seeks to amend the Social Security Act to provide the framework to implement a work for the dole scheme, as announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on 9 February 1997. The government itself has admitted that this bill is not an attempt to address Australia's high and rising rate of youth unemployment. In fact, John Howard and his then political adviser, Andrew Robb, developed the work for the dole scheme in the hope of diverting attention from scandals that were bedevilling the government at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is one of a series of measures taken by the government which demonstrate that its response to unemployment is not to generate real jobs but instead to blame and punish the unemployed for their plight. Since the Howard government was elected, we have had the so-called dole diary, the work for the dole bill and, this week, the shameful an nouncement of a plan to remove unemployment payments altogether from 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds and restrict them for many other young people from battling families. The submissions that were made by community organisations to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which considered this bill, were overwhelmingly critical.

The bill is purportedly based on the principle of mutual obligation, that is, that it is only fair that, in return for receipt of unemployment benefits, young people should work. However, what it fails to acknowledge is the obligation on the government to provide real jobs to the unemployed. According to the leaders of Australia's churches, to compel people to work merely in exchange for unemployment payments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, could I ask you to stop. Would advisers making phonecalls please go outside to do so, particularly if they are not about matters of business.

—Where were we, before we were so rudely interrupted? You might assist me, Madam Acting Deputy President—I was talking about what leaders of Australia's churches were saying, wasn't I? I referred to the leaders of some of Australia's churches. They said that to compel people to work merely in exchange for unemployment payments, `will signify on the part of this government its abrogation of the responsibility to provide for the subsistence needs of unemployed people by reducing income support entitlements to gratuitous handouts to be earned.'

SPEECH.PARA: Labor will be moving substantial amendments to this bill, which will seek to extend the government's very limited concept of mutual obligation to the much more appropriate concept of reciprocal obligation. Labor's concept of reciprocal obligation was expressed in the former Labor government's working nation program. It means that the government has an obligation not only to provide unemployment payments to those who want work and cannot get it, it also has an obligation to create real training opportunities and jobs for the unemployed.

Labor will move amendments to turn this bill into something that does do something to address Australia's high and rising rate of youth unemployment. One of the biggest problems with this bill in its present form is that it may, in fact, lead to the displacement of people in existing paid employment. Abundant evidence from overseas—in particular the United States—was presented to the Senate community affairs committee to demonstrate that similar programs there have had this effect. The government's response is that the need for work for the dole projects to represent additional work will be taken into account in the criteria for project selection.

However, one of the primary lessons from American experience of similar schemes is that legislative protection is, in fact, required to prevent displacement of paid workers. Specific laws have had to be enacted in the US state of Minnesota, for instance, to prevent work for the dole schemes destroying real jobs. There are widespread and escalating concerns about job security among workers in Australia right now. The last thing Australian workers need is more insecurity about their jobs. So Labor will be moving to amend the bill to ensure that the employment secretary requires, as a matter of law, that any new approved programs of work do not displace people currently in jobs.

The bill in its present form may also lead to unequal wages for people doing the same work, to downward pressure on wages and—according to extensive overseas experience—to the creation of a large class of working poor. Accordingly, Labor believes that is essential that the provisions of the bill be strengthened to ensure that sufficient funds are made available for participants to be paid a rate of newstart allowance equivalent to the relevant national training wage award rate for the hours the person participates in the program.

Another important issue is the need for accredited training to be incorporated into the scheme. Many organisations in their submissions and evidence to the committee high lighted concerns about the absence of training arrangements under the proposed work for the dole scheme. One of the groups that gave evidence to the committee, the UNIYA Jesuit Social Justice Centre, urged that an essential feature of any program for long‐term unemployed young people should include accredited training and/or literacy courses.

The inclusion of accredited training would eliminate wastefulness of time, energy and effort. It would also ensure logical progression for individuals in their pathway back to employment. Labor will take up this proposal in our amendments to build accredited training into the proposed scheme. We certainly do not accept the ridiculous argument that has been put by the government that, because not all training programs in the past have led to the securing of real jobs, no training at all should be included in this scheme.

Another defect in the bill is the absence of provisions for case management and supervision of participants in the proposed scheme. Many community organisations experienced in the delivery of labour market programs to Australia's unemployed believe that the arrangements envisaged under this scheme are inferior to previous labour market programs. We consider that participants in the programs established by the bill must be given the case management and supervision they require to assist them in making decisions about opportunities relevant to the program. We will be moving amendments to the bill to make this requirement explicit.

There is also a need to amend the bill to provide for additional financial support for on-costs and other aspects of the proposed projects. Amendments are required to the bill to spell out the responsibility of the Commonwealth to provide adequate financial assistance to the people responsible for conducting the programs to meet the costs of supervision, materials, workers compensation, superannuation, safety related measures, including protective clothing, and other unavoidable employment related costs such as transport and child care.

One of the central issues in the debate on this bill is whether compulsion to work for unemployment payments is justified in the absence of properly structured labour market and training programs. Let us be clear that the Labor Party does not oppose requiring the young unemployed to participate in programs or lose their payments. That is what we did in fact in Working Nation. But they have to be decent programs. They have to provide training and they have to offer the prospect of leading to a real job. The so-called work for the dole bill does nothing of the kind. In its present form, the work for the dole scheme would threaten genuine existing voluntary activity, and it would place additional social pressure on some of our most vulnerable young people who already suffer low levels of self‐esteem.

Let us listen to the words of the Salvation Army and the Sydney City Mission, who work at the sharp end of the youth unemployment problem. They have firmly stated that from their experience compulsory work for the dole schemes would not produce positive outcomes or improve the motivation of long-term unemployed people. This contradicts the unfounded assertion by the government that the compulsory nature of the government's present bill will assist people who have a severe lack of motivation. Contrary to the government's assertions, compulsory work for the dole will not in fact make participants more employable. Many prospective employers will view work for the dole participants negatively, assuming they have not participated in the projects at their own initiative and by their own choice.

The government's claims that the scheme will improve young people's work ethic are also undermined by its failure to produce any research to support the view that young people do not currently subscribe to the work ethic. In fact, the best, most comprehensive research available, conducted by organisations such as the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Commission for the Future, indicates that young people overwhelmingly do subscribe to the work ethic. The problem is that there are not enough jobs for them, and this government is doing nothing to create such jobs. It is in fact taking jobs away through its massive cuts, for example, in the Public Service.

Despite the government's rhetoric, this bill provides new and very wide ranging powers for compulsion. As the bill currently stands, the government would have the power to compel anyone, irrespective of how old they are, irrespective of how long they have been unemployed, irrespective of where they live, to participate in a work for the dole scheme for an indefinite period, until they get a job, at the national training wage award rate of pay and without any of the protections afforded to other Australian workers.

What we say is that this is not acceptable. If the government does intend to create only 10,000 places and these are in fact largely to be filled on a voluntary basis, then no case has been made for the inclusion of powers for compulsion in this bill. Accordingly, Labor will be moving an amendment to delete the provisions of the bill which allow the secretary to compel unemployed people to participate in the work for the dole scheme.

Another flaw in this bill is that it prescribes that participation in work for the dole projects does not give rise to an employer-employee relationship for the purposes of workers compensation, occupational health and safety, superannuation and industrial relations laws. This means that the young and vulnerable participants in this scheme would have no recourse to the legal protections given to all other workers in Australia. Labor will move amendments to delete the government's attempt to remove these protections.

The bill also seeks to provide that decisions to approve a program of work for unemployment payment are not subject to internal review and are not decisions that can be reviewed by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Labor will move an amendment to ensure that unemployed people's rights of appeal are protected. Our amendments to the bill will provide the Senate with an opportuni ty to do what this government failed to do in its budget, and that is to create a decent skills training program to help turn back Australia's rising tide of unemployment. I commend the opposition's approach on this bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —If today we were being asked to consider a trial work for the dole scheme for young volunteers, then the Australian Democrats would have absolutely no trouble in voting for it. But the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill is not about that, unfortunately. This legislation does not even meet the description by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of his work for the dole as a pilot program for the young unemployed. This bill is about exempting the current Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr David Kemp, from any future parliamentary scrutiny of the conditions he sets for unemployed people in need of income support.

SPEECH.PARA: When you look at the bill you see that it is open‐ended, and I think we need to draw attention to that. We have an ongoing discussion in this parliament about the struggle between the executive and the parliament. I do not think the Senate should be willing to give Minister Kemp, as an appointed official, and any minister who comes after him powers which would normally be exercised by the parliament. I do not think we should be willing to give him the blank cheque.

We may have been willing to have endorsed some future changes in this area after the pilot scheme had been completed and after it had been evaluated. Then we would have been in a position to know whether this scheme should continue. But, if the Senate passes this bill unamended today, we are denying the parliament the opportunity for that kind of further scrutiny. We will not have the chance to oppose any extensions that we think are unreasonable or beyond the test of fairness. If we pass this bill unamended today, theoretically there would be nothing stopping a future minister from forcing retrenched, old breadwinners to work for the dole or have their families cut off from income support.

That is why the Democrats will be moving to insert a sunset clause into the legislation, to actually make the government implement what the Prime Minister said he was doing—a trial for the young unemployed, at least for those who still get the dole, and to allow parliament to assess the trial before considering whether it should be adopted as a matter of course for all unemployed Australians. I am tired of being asked yet again to vote on the `big picture' bill and let the government fill in the details afterwards. That is what happened with the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill, and we found out, `Oh, PS, it's voluntary voting.'

That reminds me of one of the philosophical inconsistencies in this government. At the moment we are having this great passionate debate about why voluntary voting is important and how terrible it is to compel people. In this bill they are totally happy to compel vulnerable, unemployed young Australians to work for their dole. There is a fundamental inconsistency in their approach.

In the months since this proposal was first announced, the Prime Minister and the minister have consistently presented this scheme as nothing more than a trial work program for young unemployed people. This bill, though, contains no mention of a pilot program, no mention of any age restriction on those who can be compelled to participate in the program and no mention of when this bill would finish. It goes on forever. So it is a very significant one for all unemployed Australians, not just for young unemployed Australians.

Let us face it: with this government's record on job creation, the potential for so many Australians to be caught up in the ramifications of this bill is very high. In the past two years alone over 75,000 Australians have been retrenched in Australian manufacturing, construction and retail industries. So there is huge potential there for people to be caught up in this bill. All of these people could be forced to participate in compulsory work for the dole as the bill now stands. Perhaps a more appropriate title and certainly a more honest title for this bill would be the `Social Security Legislation Amendment (Compulsory Work for Everyone on Unemployment Benefits) Bill'.

I do not want the minister to misrepresent the Democrats' position on work experience programs for the unemployed. We are not opposed to them in principle. We believe that voluntary work programs which involve at least some degree of training and which are properly planned, staffed, managed and resourced have a great deal to offer unemployed people and the communities in which they live. The value of them has been spelt out by others. Yes, they probably can help build self-esteem and self‐worth, because they can provide a sense of purpose and structure to a day and hopefully a sense of achievement at the end of it.

But, along with many community organisations and individuals with vast experience in dealing with unemployed Australians, we do not believe that the same can be said for the outcome of work programs which rely on compulsion. Organisations such as ACOSS, Welfare Rights, AYPAC, the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission and the Australian Council of Volunteering have all voiced very strong opposition to the government's proposal to compel unemployed people to work for the dole. Many other organisations, including Anglicare, the Brotherhood of St Laurence—the one the minister quoted in question time yesterday—the Salvation Army, the Victoria Social Justice Council and the Moreland City Council in Victoria, have already said that they will not sponsor any work for the dole program in which people are compelled to participate.

In response to that, the government has said, unless potential sponsors such as these groups are willing to sign a standard contract which makes provision for the referral of compulsorily referred, potential participants, they will be ruled out. That means that these kinds of community organisations, which would have been willing to sponsor a voluntary work for the dole program, will not be eligible to sponsor any program at all. I think that is a silly thing to do, because I am sure these people would have done a terrific job in monitoring, supervising and matching up the skills of volunteers.

My own research strongly suggests that finding enough organisations to sponsor the proposed pilot programs may not be quite as easy as the government suggests, although we do note that there will be 10,000 participants in this scheme in regional and rural areas with high unemployment. But it would have been better to have in the first instance the goodwill of the majority of community groups who would have been good sponsors.

On the matter of compulsion, I think you can mount a strong argument that compelling unemployed people to work for the dole effectively punishes them for the failure of the economic managers of this country to actually create enough jobs. This is shifting the blame for unemployment away from the economy and the government and placing it instead on the shoulders of those who are the victims of unemployment.

There is a difference between reciprocal and mutual obligation. Reciprocal obligation implies that those who are requiring young people to turn up compulsorily actually have an equal obligation to provide them with something decent to do. We do not know enough about the detail of what young people are going to be asked to do. All the Prime Minister could say was, `Some of them can go to the airports and meet and greet tourists.' That was the amount of detail that the Prime Minister of this country had on offer when he announced this scheme.

It is not surprising that, after so many months of populist propaganda from this government, polls show that there is widespread community support for compelling young people to work for unemployment benefits, and that will last until we have an opportunity to assess how it worked and until families have real experience to apply to the theory. But the assumption that young unemployed people do not want to work is, I think, fallacious, and it is not something that has been borne out by the Democrats' own experience or the experience of many organisations that work with young unemployed people.
Mr McAuliffe, from the Brotherhood of St Laurence, recently told a Senate committee that most young unemployed people are very keen to work in his experience. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Our experience shows high rates of self-referral by job‐seekers to our programs. In the case of young job‐seekers, self-referral to programs can be as high as 80 per cent . . . This hardly constitutes bludging, laziness or unwillingness to participate.

BREAK.PARA: If this government had just been a bit more flexible and creative, we could have been debating something really worth while today. There has been a lot of interest in this country in the example of the Blair government's work for welfare proposal in the United Kingdom. I hope our Prime Minister brings some details of this home with him but, unfortunately, we are debating this today.

Tony Blair's package gives unemployed young people choice. This government is supposedly big on choice—low on compulsion, big on choice—except in this bill. In Mr Blair's proposal, young unemployed people have choices. Their first choice is a private sector job where employers are offered £60 per week for six months to take on an unemployed person or £70 if they take on a young person who has been unemployed for more than two years. Their second choice is a job in the voluntary sector. Their third choice is a job with an environmental task force. Their fourth choice is full-time study for young people with no qualifications. Isn't that a much more flexible and relevant policy package than the no choice we are being offered here today?

While the British government says that, if young people do not take up one of these options, they will be subject to a 40 per cent reduction in their unemployment benefits, I think that is acceptable under these conditions. They have four choices.

We also know how Mr Blair has funded this program, and this government is not willing to find the funding through a tax on the windfall profits of the privatisation of utilities. Boy, we could make a lot of money in this country from that. It might have been a better way to use the Telstra money, mightn't it?

Some concerns have been raised about the potential substitution effect that work for the dole programs may have on paid jobs. As Senator Faulkner said, this is something we have to pay attention to in the committee stage and in monitoring the impact of this bill.

There were a number of comparisons made in the recent Senate committee hearings between this government's work for the dole program and the workfare program in the United States. The worrying thing is that evidence in the United States is now showing that many low skilled paid jobs have been lost as a result of their version of this. A recent article in the New York Times reported:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Job displacement is entering the debate over welfare reform. Across the country thousands of people on welfare are going to work, but often not at new jobs created for them as President Clinton envisioned when he signed the welfare‐to‐work legislation last fall. Frequently they do work once done by regular employees.

BREAK.PARA: I know the government does not want that to happen, but it is very hard to say how it is going to prevent that that from happening. That is why I think the government must closely monitor the effect these programs will have on the availability of paid jobs.

The importance of training has been largely overlooked in this proposal. Although the minister, Dr Kemp, has stated that training will be part of work for the dole programs where appropriate—good, I am glad about that—the department has, nonetheless, made it very clear that work for the dole programs are not intended to be training programs. The lack of any formal link between work for the dole programs, training and real jobs at the end is of great concern to the Democrats and, as I said, to organisations which are experienced in working with unemployed people.

Work for the dole programs are not a substitute for job creation. I do not believe that compelling people to turn up to work will automatically instil some kind of magical work ethic—a Liberal version of it. Of course, 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds now denied the dole ironically cannot be compelled to work for it. As the Minister for Social Security, (Senator Newman) is in the chamber at the moment, and because I have not had an opportunity over the last couple of days to do so, I want to take the opportunity now, in the last few minutes I have, to deal with her zealous embrace of the Daily Telegraph editorial which grossly misrepresented my view on the new youth allowance.

I want to point out to her and to this chamber that, when passing her in the press gallery, I asked her personally and in good faith, `Minister, could you tell me where my facts were incorrect, because we did get some of them from your office late at night? I would be very interested to know, in good faith, where the inaccuracies were.' The good faith was returned, of course, with a further misrepresentation the next day in question time. I did not receive the personal written advice that I asked for—the minister, as usual, took the opportunity to distort and misrepresent.

In regard to my own words, I accept responsibility for one inaccurate use of the word `student'. I did say `student child' when I used the example of an unemployed child, and I wrongly attributed the dole rate to a student child. I accept that. It is hardly a hanging offence, and it hardly detracts from the argument I was mounting about the financial stresses placed on families. I did not say that teenagers have an automatic right to taxpayer funded drinks and entertainment. I did say that many families, perhaps those where one or both parents are unemployed, are already struggling to make ends meet—and that is undeniable.

This rearrangement of benefits, this denial of unemployment benefits to 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds, will make it more difficult for those families, and other families with below average incomes but which are still knocked out by the new means test, to find what they used to get—$145 a fortnight. Parents of these 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds will be under financial stress to find the money for the few normal daily needs of teenagers, trivialised by the minister in the Daily Telegraph as lollies: a few snacks now and then, transport costs now and then and the occasional movie.
