I sometimes wonder if the ministers in this government who have large share portfolios and their own shopping centres have much personal experience of the impact of unemployment on families. If they did, I really do not believe they could be so callous and mean, and I really do not think they could choose the trade‐offs that they have of rewarding some and making victims of the others.

That takes me back to the beginning of this bill. We should not blame the victims of the government's policy failure to create jobs. We should not say to them, `You're the scapegoats. You bear the responsibility.' Yes, we should provide them with voluntary opportunities that the best structured programs like this could offer. But this is a limited, narrow propagandist opportunity. I think the Tony Blair comparison shows this government what they could have done instead of what they have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens oppose the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill 1997, and oppose the concept of compulsory work for the dole schemes in a society in which 810,000 people do not have jobs, not because they do not measure up, have not tried to find jobs, do not want jobs or are not desperate to find fulfilment through work like the rest of us, but because those jobs are not there. The primary responsibility for parliaments, in particular for governments and in especial measure for relevant ministers, is to fix that situation so that jobs are available for everybody in our society. But that has not been done.

BREAK.PARA: Coming out of that there is a fairly widespread feeling in our society that those people who are in jobs should not have to pay taxes to support those who do not have jobs. It is a miserly, selfish, short‐sighted and vindictive way of thinking, lacking in the compassion that would come from a simple experience of the desperation and depression that so often comes out of failing to be able to get a job.

The reality for hundreds and thousands of Australians is that they cannot get jobs, because the jobs are not there. Sailing into the middle of this comes Senator Newman's and Prime Minister Howard's viewpoint that the best way to tackle this problem is to punish the innocent—in particular, through this formula, which the government itself pejoratively calls `work for the dole scheme'. Let's pick on those amongst the innocent who are least able to get themselves back into the work force. Let's pick on those who are least able, through no fault of their own, to get a job in a nation which has a social complex which denies them that opportunity. Let's feed into the philosophy of those people who feel they ought not pay taxes at all—or if they do, it ought not to be going to other people in less fortunate circumstances—because it is a vote getter, sadly enough, by creating a punishment program for the people who are in the most invidious circumstances as far as work and income, stability and outlook in our society are concerned. Here we have it in this bill, with this noxious little title `work for the dole' on the top of it.

The Greens would not mind near as much if it were a voluntary program, even if it did not have a training component—and this does not. We would cavil with it, because we believe that when government puts expenditure into creating artificial work programs like this there ought to be a positive outcome, that people through that process ought to get skills which will better enable them to find a job further down the line.

But not this government; it scrapped all that. It wanted to wipe $1.8 billion out of the budget last year by getting rid of training programs, because it had other priorities to meet, not least keeping up the $800 million a year which it hands across to the job shedding mining corporations so that they can the better pay for their chief executive officers with the rampant pay rises they have had over the last decade or two—six of whom in BHP alone will take home $1 million this year in our increasingly divided society, helped by this government handing BHP alone this year, on a platter as a tax rebate, the sum of $112 million. It is perverse; it is harsh; it is heartless; it is discriminatory.

On the one hand, we will punish those people who cannot get a job because we have not provided it for them; on the other hand, we will hand the million‐dollar executives in this country $100 million on a platter so that their shareholders—and in particular they themselves—can have a better profit line at the end of the day and can work out a better pay package. In that way, they do not have to scrimmage on $1 million but they can bump it up to $2 million—or, as one of those executives has got, $3 million in the coming year.

Just this morning, the Hobart Mercury runs a story from the Australian Bureau of Statistics which shows how this country is being increasingly divided, as the rich get richer and the poor get poorer. One of the things that immediately hits the eye is that teenagers who are working now are paid less than those who were in employ in the early 1980s. What is going on here?

Not least, corporate ethics. We have heard overnight how McDonald's did not come out smelling of roses from the McLibel case in Britain because, amongst other things, it has been found to have been depressing the wages of young people. It is not the only multi‐billion dollar corporation which has executives on obscene take‐home packages and at the same time is pressing down the income of those at the other end of the spectrum. And here we have a government that is aiding and abetting that process.
The report in the Hobart Mercury goes on to point out:

PARA.EMPHASIS: In 1994, the top 20% of Australian households received 40% of the total disposable income averaging $1205 a week.

BREAK.PARA: That is the rich. To continue:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The bottom 20% of households received a 6% share of disposable income averaging $175 a week.

BREAK.PARA: That is the poor. So we have this formula of 20 per cent of Australians having a household disposable income of $1,200, and 20 per cent of Australians living next door or in the western suburbs getting an average of $175. How can we countenance that? How come we are not addressing that in here today? How come we are not putting a lid on those million‐dollar pay packages? What about that as a means of getting some social equity into our nation, which lives by the ethic of a fair go?

Instead of that, we have got this nasty piece of legislation, which says, `Let's punish the young who can't get a job, who are down there in those $175 a week households. Let's make scapegoats of them. Having cut out their access to training schemes under the previous government's One Nation program, we'll make them work for the dole and we'll call it work for the dole and we won't skill them while we are doing it. Worse still, we'll set up other legislation that—through privatising the Commonwealth Employment Service, the CES—is going to enable those for‐profit private agencies, which will place people in jobs in the future, to get rid of the long‐term unemployed and skip them across into this work for the dole scheme.'

The Greens will be amending that other legislation to prevent that happening—to prevent these private job finding agencies making a profit, as they will do because that is the way it works, out of placing people in jobs and from skipping the hard people on their books across to a work for the dole program temporarily—get them off the books and, if they do not like that, they end up with nothing. There will be a fall‐out rate from this scheme, and the government knows that. Some people are not going to be able to hack it. Where are those people going to go because they will have no social support? They have turned down a job that they did not want and which had a pejorative term and label put across it by the minister anyway. They are going to be on the streets, and they are going to be knocking on the doors of welfare agencies.

As I said to somebody here yesterday, it is as if a few government ministers have been to the United States, have seen in the streets the panhandlers who have got no support and have thought, `Australia's falling behind. We'll have to get some stimulus into the panhandle scene in this country.' That is a trite thing to say, but it has very serious ramifications because that is what is going to happen. As the poor get poorer and the rich get richer under this sort of scheme and as the government feeds the primitive and punitive streak that there is in some people towards those who are least able to get a job in this country, the division in society is going to come back and visit us all.

Further down the line we are going to have more people begging in the streets, and we are going to have more aggressive panhandlers, because people have got to survive. We are going to have more locks on people's doors and we are going to have more advertisements on television about alarm systems for your house. That is the fall‐out. You do not bring in this sort of program, as part of an overall vindictive attitude towards the poor and the jobless in your nation, without the rich and the so‐called `secure' having a penalty clause written into their contract as well.

To people who do not believe that, I say, `Go to the United States, where 35 million people are living below the poverty line, walk down Market Street in San Francisco to the wrong end and see how secure you feel there if you are done up in furs, pearls and shiny boots.' It is a no‐go area for the wealthy in the central city. That is the prescription this government is bringing to this country little by little. It is eroding the fair go that we have had in the past and leading us towards the divisive rich versus poor prescription which mars a feeling of wellbeing, which deprives people of security, and which defrauds America of its own token label as `the land of the free'. It is nothing like it. If we are to retain our label of `the land of the fair go', we have got to turn away from this sort of direction being taken by this government.

It will not hurt to elaborate on what Senator Kernot was saying about the American system. In New York, there has been a massive dislocation of the work force in many city jobs by forced work schemes. People who were previously working in park maintenance, street cleaning and receptionist areas for the city are now replaced by people on much lower wages with much poorer conditions on forced work—read `work for the dole'—schemes. It is estimated that for every three jobs created on work for the dole, two jobs are lost which have proper wages, proper conditions and long‐term security. So the price of instituting and peddling this failed prescription here in Australia is going to be some diminution in the long‐term jobs available with proper wages and adequate conditions in this country. In other words, it is going to worsen the situation as far as full‐time employment is concerned. What a silly prescription. What an ostrich attitude. What a failure to learn from what has gone wrong elsewhere in this country.

We should be working on the basis of a mutual obligation in this country where we recognise that there are not the jobs to go round, that those of us who have jobs have a special obligation to improve that situation and to ensure that, of all the things we do, we do not punish those who are not as lucky as ourselves. But that is what this legislation is: it is punishment legislation; it is division legislation; it is rich versus poor legislation; it is put the problems on the sidewalk for people a few years down the line to pick up legislation. It is nasty, vindictive and greedy, and it should have no place in this `fair go' country of ours.

As far as Tasmania is concerned, if you take a pro rata guess it might create 300 jobs in a state that has got horrendous youth unemployment. It is going to create a lot more problems than that. If we take the figures for New York that I used a while ago, it will very likely displace, if it is kept up in the long run, dozens of full‐time jobs in its wake.

The problem is that is it going to give those people who are given the short straw, who draw the marble, in this punitive lottery the label `forced to work because they wouldn't otherwise want to work'. That is the idea behind this and it is going to pick them out in their own communities. Why couldn't this program have been voluntary? You cannot tell me that with 810,00 unemployed Australians there would not have been a queue to take up 10,000 voluntary placements. Of course there would. People tell you time and time again that they will do anything to get out of the boredom, frustration and emptiness of not having a job.

I will tell you why it is not voluntary. It is because the real philosophy behind this is not help; it is punishment. It is a nasty streak of vindictiveness that comes from the rich and is aimed at the poor. Sadly, it is as old as human society itself. Wouldn't you think we could be doing better in 1997? Wouldn't you think that the combined intellect of this government would be matched with a combined compassion which would dismiss an idea like this at the outset? Instead, it has gone through the House of Representatives and here it is in the Senate, aimed at the least able, the least fortunate and the least hopeful of young people in our society.

It might give some people on high incomes a good feeling. It might give some of those people who believe taxes per se are bad some passing smile that retribution is being wrought somewhere on some of those people they do not like to see hanging around because they do not have a job. But it is unprincipled, unethical and unfair in a country that calls itself `the place of a fair go'.

Every senator in this chamber was elected on a prime mandate from the Australian people. We were charged with the responsibility to ensure a future for all Australians. The government was elected to provide security, work and a sense of worth. PARA.EMPHASIS: Any kind of make‐work scheme which does not provide active employment support and training, holds a very limited capacity to generate real jobs in an economy . . . PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . signify on the part of this government its abrogation of the responsibility to provide for the subsistence needs of the unemployed people by reducing income support entitlements to gratuitous `handouts' to be earned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor government provided suitable, relevant training and active labour market programs. This policy was evident in our practical programs such as jobskills, LEAP and new work opportunities.

What we had under Working Nation was a working, mutually beneficial partnership that had, implicit within its structure, a governmental responsibility to the individual and to the Australian people. By the government's own admission, there will be discrimination against those young unemployed in regional and rural areas. They will be compelled to work for the dole. This government has once again abrogated its responsibility in this matter.

This is of real concern, not only for us on this side of the chamber but for the community groups themselves. This issue was canvassed by the Youth Action Policy Association of New South Wales who said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: There is a serious lack of detail in relation to the conditions under which young people will be working, the occupational health and safety conditions they will be subjected to, the accessibility of compensation if they are injured . . .

SPEECH.PARA: What this abrogation of work conditions amounts to is an invitation to be sued. What employer is going to leave himself or herself open to court cases?

Where does this leave the unemployed who are compelled to take the job—a job that puts at risk their health and safety? It is perfectly clear how little respect this government has for the unemployed. Will there be personal safety equipment provided for work for the dole recipients, like those provided to green corps workers? Who will pay for the safety equipment? Will the employer be reimbursed for safety expenditure or will it be up to the unemployed to provide their own?

Considering the high percentage of accidents that occur—in construction, a 22 per cent chance of an accident; in agriculture, forestry and fishing, a 24 per cent chance of an accident; in health and community services, an 18 per cent chance of an accident—you would think it would be prudent of the government to insure these people. You would think that that would be only sensible. The only recognition that the government gives to those expenses is to say that they will give an extra $10 per week for work related costs. This may cover bus fares for one week, but that would really be about it.

To fit out someone for manual labour to ensure a reasonable level of safety would cost around $271. For example, to buy a pair of steel‐capped boots will cost $79, an illuminated vest costs $26 and a pair of gloves costs around $14. How on earth are people going to find the money to pay for these items? Where will they get it from? These are essential items that are required to maintain a basic level of safety in the workplace.

This is in direct contrast to the Green Corps reality, which is, essentially, a quasi‐environmental peace corps for the employed, for the lucky and for those who can afford it.

This government his admitted that up and running Green Corps projects have 12 per cent of participants that have been long-term unemployed, seven per cent that have been unemployed for less than 12 months but more than six months, 30 per cent that have been unemployed for less than six months and a staggering 51 per cent who have never been unemployed.

To further contrast the two coalition government policies, upon completion of a Green Corps project, the participants will receive $500 to assist with further educational training. To make it very clear, Green Corps members receive a training allowance, safety gear, accredited training and money upon completion. Work for the dole participants receive no training, no safety gear, no Commonwealth protection and no real jobs at the end of the project. Where is the equality and social justice in the work for dole bill?

You have to wonder how existing workers in jobs that have been earmarked for this policy are feeling. What stops the employer from totally staffing his or her business with unemployed people? I hope that that will not be the case. I hope that the government is going to put mechanisms in to ensure that that is not the case. I would be interested in a response to that.

At the moment they are free and there is an endless supply. There is no need to secure their future, safety or retirement. There will be no union involvement of course—we could not possibly have that with this government, could we?—and the employer can threaten them because of the compulsion element within this bill.

Work for the dole is the ultimate in casualisation. It provides employers with free, casual and non-unionised labour—a casual worker who is free from superannuation, holidays, sick leave, workers compensation, overtime, award rates of pay and payroll tax, something you would think this government would be interested in. The worker even has to pay for his or her own safety equipment. If that is not right, I would appreciate a response to that. What next? Deductions for capital equipment used?

Professor Robert Mullaly, a New Brunswick critic of this type of policy, said that `workfare programs are "cash cows" for "business people"'. This type of unemployment scheme is open to corruption, and for corrupt businesses there will be the avenue to eliminate troublemakers by replacing them with welfare recipients. Again, if that is wrong, I would appreciate amplification on and clarification of that.

BREAK.PARA: The migrant employment task force also gave evidence, and I quote from the minority report:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . that in New York unemployed workers are increasingly being forced to do tasks normally assigned to full‐time workers. They referred also to the Ontario works project where: the use of unpaid welfare recipients to perform social services may prove very compelling for cash‐strapped municipalities.

BREAK.PARA: These are existing overseas experiences from which we really should learn.

He went on to say, `To keep finding useful work that is not demeaning isn't easy.' This is New Zealand, which is not that far away. Why don't we learn from this?

The overseas evidence clearly shows that these schemes have been used to replace existing workers in paid employment. This is happening most in the United States where one state—and I think Senator Faulkner has already referred to this—Minnesota, actually had to introduce legislation to stop the practice of replacing paid workers with welfare recipients.

I say to this government: in the interests of all Australians, especially our youth, put real job creation back on the agenda, not mickey mouse stuff, not kicking unemployed people, not trying to pretend you are doing something when you are not—the statistics simply do not bear that out—and implement a sensible training program so that we can have a decent skills base when we go into the next century. We are in desperate danger of becoming a deskilled nation. That is the reality. Most business pundits will admit that. Even conservative ones admit that. That is the reality. This is a very depressing situation.

This bill provides no future, no training, a one‐way street of obligation and no protection. I say to the government: remember your fundamental duty to protect and provide financial help. You have a mandate to provide real jobs, not promote civil conscription. You have a responsibility to provide national portable training. You have a responsibility and obligation to all Australians to do this. In fact, it is your moral and social duty.

Ultimately, work for the dole will be seen by the Australian people for what it is—a shame and a wasted opportunity to really do something positive for unemployed people. It will divide Australian society and discriminate against those with the least rights under the Howard government—the jobless. This bill is not going to lead us any closer to a working nation and it will not provide a future for our next generation facing the new millennium.

It is another classic example of scapegoat politics: instead of dealing with the types of development, the investment patterns and the employment patterns which eat jobs rather than create jobs, instead of dealing with what is happening with our trade, instead of dealing with what is happening with companies simply downing tools, closing down and going overseas and playing off one country against another, which is what has been happening over the last few years, let us go to diversionary tactics. Let us blame the victims. Let us blame the people who are suffering most from those changes. This is what is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times, in states like Western Australia, we have seen situations where substance abusers and petrol sniffers have been threatened with gaol. Just this morning I heard on the radio the Western Australian minister for education and the Deputy Premier saying that they are going to punish those who do not fit into the school system and fine the parents of truant children $100.

The community youth allowance once again punishes the square pegs that do not fit into the round holes. The government is saying, `If you don't fit into the school system we'll punish you.' BREAK.PARA: Labor should shoulder some responsibility for this kind of response. Because of the con of Working Nation, that it was a new, big spending program, it has been possible for the coalition to remove spending without Labor's being able to fight back in any effective way. The coalition has been able to pull out a couple of billion dollars because Labor was not able to say, `With only $5 billion allocated to it, it never was a big spending program in the first place,' because they established the myth that it was. The media picked up the two‐way myth, ran with it and we are therefore left with the situation where there is not enough training or support for young people. The government is looking for tactics to try to hide the statistics—and this is one of them.

There has been $15 million set aside for only 10,000 places in the scheme around Australia. The work for the dole scheme, as has been mentioned, has no training component. Initially, the scheme was open to all ages, but only 18‐ to 24‐year‐olds unemployed for at least six months would be targeted for compulsory participation. However, on 19 March this age limit was dropped as the legislation was introduced into the Senate. Participants will work for two six‐hour days if aged 18 to 20 and 2½ six‐hour days if aged 21 or over. This is based on the national training wage figures of $7.40 per hour and $9.30 per hour. They are required to work for a maximum of six months each and will be paid an extra $10 a week—whoopy‐do—in recognition of the unavoidable costs of working. Regional areas of high unemployment are to be targeted.

In the correspondence that I have received, I have seen two major arguments. One is a general argument that has been put by the Australian Council of Social Services and the other comes from groups voicing concerns stemming from international conventions, including a convention of the International Labour Organisation. I will deal first with the arguments put by organisations like ACOSS.

ACOSS argues that the work for the dole scheme contains two damaging features: it is punitive and it is compulsory—with no training component and no benefits. Therefore, the scheme `blames the victim' and implies that unemployment is the outcome of personal characteristics, such as work motivation and self-esteem, rather than a product of structural unemployment. When are we going to deal with that in Australia?

The work for the dole scheme also fundamentally changes the basis on which social security benefits are paid to unemployed people. It changes the notion and basis of payments known as reciprocal responsibility. The current system is that governments have a responsibility to provide positive employment assistance and social security entitlements. The reciprocal obligation is that unemployed people have a responsibility to seek employment and participate in employment and training programs that are genuinely designed to improve their employment prospects. To force unemployed people to work and not provide any positive employment assistance in the work for the dole scheme fundamentally changes a set of rights and entitlements which has been in place for the last 50 years—since the Depression.

To make it clear, the scheme should be made voluntary. Positive employment assistance programs like labour market programs must be restarted. The scheme's objectives are vague and ill‐considered. If the one of the scheme's objectives is self-esteem, then the program should be voluntary. If one of the scheme's objectives is to improve employment prospects, then there must be well structured training and placements should be tailored to meet the needs of the people.

The government should not shift the reciprocal rights agreements already in place in unemployment assistance. Any voluntary scheme that is set up should include an adequate incidentals allowance and legislation to implement it. Currently, there are elements of the work for the dole scheme which can be implemented by regulation. That is obviously a concern.

Work for the dole scheme workers could displace genuine volunteer workers and create a two tiered system consisting of volunteers by choice and volunteers by compulsion, which changes the view of volunteer work and changes the dynamics of voluntary organisations.

This is another really important thing. In the last few weeks, the government has tried to shut up many voluntary organisations in Australia and told them that they were only allowed to do this work for nothing or for very little, that they were not allowed to speak up or criticise the government in any way. Here we go: over time, they might change the dynamics. Not only do they threaten people with funding cuts if they do not shut up but they will also be able to control the people in voluntary organisations and perhaps force voluntary organisations to be minders of unemployed people.
The work for the dole scheme needs occupational health and safety protection, industrial relations protection and advocacy. This is a huge failing in relation to this program.

As I mentioned before, the other group we get arguments from are people concerned about Australia's obligations to basic human rights. The work for the dole scheme may infringe International Labour Organisation Convention No. 29 known as the Forced Labour Convention. Articles 5 and 6 of this convention prevent the use of forced compulsory labour for the benefit of private individuals and companies. The government has to guarantee that the work for the dole scheme is restricted to only community and not for profit organisations if it is not to be in contravention of this convention, which Australia ratified in 1932. We are not talking about anything radical or current; we are talking about something at the time of the Depression—1932. Are we going to be in contravention of this? Will the government guarantee that this will be the case?

The principles of this convention against forced or compulsory labour are also found in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Work for the dole may be in violation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is part of the Human Rights Convention, second covenant on human rights. It is potentially a violation of part III, article 8(2), which says that `no one shall be held in servitude' and possibly 8(3)(a) which says, `No one shall be required to perform forced or compulsory labour.' The exception, 8(3)(c)(iv), says the term `compul sory labour' shall not include `any work or service which forms part of normal civil obligations'. This does not apply since this work is not expected of all citizens. A normal civil obligation is meant for nations where, for example, all citizens are expected to assist in irrigation maintenance. But that is for all citizens, except for particular exceptions like the disabled.

If it is taken that it is a voluntary action, then there is no guarantee of the dole or legitimate work and the government is potentially in violation of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, article 11(2), which says that the state has a duty to ensure that everyone is free from hunger. The condition of work may also be in violation of article 7, which says that remuneration for work must be on the basis of fair and equal remuneration relative to work of equal value, and also potentially of article 8, which guarantees the right to union activity and collective bargaining. Guess what? If it is not considered work there is not necessarily access to a union. And bargaining—bargaining for what? For poverty? None of this applies under this scheme. I wonder who the government is going to blame if this is made public overseas along with the litany of other recent shameful decisions here in this country.

Long‐term unemployment blew out, according to figures published in April by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, by some 16,500. The government must address long‐term unemployment with sound education and training schemes rather than forcing the long‐term unemployed to work and therefore excising them from the unemployment statistics. This is cheating, to say the least. The government is abandoning its responsibilities to the long‐term unemployed, forcing them to work against the principles of international law. It is giving them work which has no beneficial training component or self‐esteem benefits because it is compulsory. The government can forget about these people if it can wipe them off the unemployment statistics, allowing them to be thoroughly unaccountable.

In summary, the change in reciprocal obligations blames the victim at the same time as the government has abandoned the long‐term unemployed without any genuine assistance and has literally attempted to wipe them off the books. This scheme is a whitewash and immoral, to say the least.

I also want to talk about some of the issues for those people who often do not fit into anybody's system and who somehow have trouble being recognised sometimes even as human beings within this system. Currently, personal files on each dole recipient are held by the Department of Social Security and the CES. There is already evidence of this information being used to victimise and to stereotype people. CES and DSS offices display sexism, homophobia and a lack of understanding in respect of illness, disability and so on. Through government agencies, though, there is accessible recourse to a social worker or counsellor in each office or region and a complaints board and so on. Of course, ultimately these officers are responsible to the minister.

The offices are not well equipped enough to meet the current needs of unemployed people safeguarding their own privacy. Information being signed over to private tender companies in order to fulfil dole requirements will result in less security of information and fewer safeguards against information being mismanaged and privacy being breached and used as a tool against unemployed people. If you do not think this is going to happen, try being an unemployed person—the insect on the end of somebody's pin.

The decision is arbitrary. This bill will allow enormous powers of discretion and arbitration, mostly given to the employment secretary, in deciding what is fit work for reasons of unemployment. Instead of services being delivered by the CES we can see that the tendering process for many people has favoured church and conservatively oriented groups. With good intentions, the Uniting Church, the Salvation Army, the Perth City Mission and so on deliver related services. But, with the current prejudice that has been apparent in the government service delivery process, there is even less of a safety net against discrimination after the services have been tendered for. The trend towards Christian moral majority groups winning tenders for employment services suggests things will even get worse. Perhaps there will be a particular group of people who will be singled out in this direction.

The role of the employment secretary will devolve decision making to local private service provider agencies which will affect the client and will be increasingly arbitrary and based on local belief systems rather than on federal or state law against discrimination and so on. The employment secretary is not required by law to fully inform clients in regard to their rights. A client of the work for the dole scheme could end up being unaware of when they will no longer be forced to work for their payment and at what point they can refuse jobs which they feel are not meeting their needs.

The resulting effect upon individuals will be less power to have input into what type of activity that person is interested in engaging in; for example, career choices, training opportunities, lifestyle choices, style of job investigation, issues of self‐presentation and the issues of self‐identification. The social effects of this formal disempowering process include alienation from government service provision, alienation from the community and reinforced feelings of having nothing to offer the community. The long‐term effects will be felt on the economy with the placement of unemployed people in low socioeconomic groups with no self‐determined power to change or affect that situation. That is a recipe for social disruption, for alienation and for social dysfunction.

In relation to industrial protection, workers compensation and the occupational health and safety act will not be applicable for the people who are on the work for the dole scheme. Injuries or occupational health and safety issues cannot be taken through the usual processes, through tribunals et cetera. Instead, an individual will have to apply common law practice to sue the service provider, which, under this bill, would not have to be covered by workers compensation insurance for that worker.

Are we creating a false economy through slave wages, loss of award wages and minimum income safety net? The work for the dole scheme will result in those subject to it working for slave wages. It creates a false economy of a job ready employment group prepared to work for very low wages. In actuality, people will be forced into these programs. This false economy can do nothing but reinforce the continuation of the same scheme creating no jobs and resulting in fewer jobs. The Greens (WA) resist and oppose this draconian legislation.
