It took place, as I recall it, on the Sunday program, following a week of headlines about the Senator Woods and the Roxanne affair. That was the environment in which this announcement was made. It was an announcement which was out of the blue. It was not an announcement which was contained in any policy document which was before the electorate. The work for the dole policy proposal was announced to get the Senator Woods and Roxanne affair off the front pages of the nation's newspapers and off the news bulletins at least for a time. This was policy making on the run. This was policy making not based upon an appropriate assessment of the real worth of the matter but policy making based on opinion poll motiva tion and on the establishment of a smokescreen for the Senator Woods matter.

What is this policy proposal borne, as I said, out of motives other than good policy motives? This is a policy to create a pilot program—that is what we are told—requiring young unemployed people to work for their unemployment benefit—that is, if they get it after recent announcements. It was to target 18‐ to 24‐year‐olds who had been unemployed for six months with an emphasis on those who had been unemployed for more than 12 months. Other age groups could be involved, it was said, in various circumstances and localities.

It was to be largely voluntary but there was to be a element of compulsion—two days work for 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds; 2½ days work for 21‐year‐olds—and a maximum of six months work was to be involved. There is to be—certainly under Commonwealth law—no health and safety rights or workers compensation rights. The participants are not to be deemed employees under any Commonwealth legislation. There are issues that arise from that, which I may deal with later, time permitting. This was to be the basis of a pilot program involving community assistance and development projects, with 10,000 participants over the life of the program, which was to be 18 months.

The aims were announced and they were: to raise young unemployed people's work ethic through fostering appropriate work habits and attitudes and improving self‐esteem; to involve the local community both in the projects that provide work for the dole for young people and in helping young people at the end of the projects; to provide communities with projects that are considered to be of value to the communities; and to ensure that participants in the community accept the principle of mutual obligation.

The first three aims of these are, in the main, uncontroversial and supportable, but there are issues, of course, which must be addressed when you actually look at the bill which is before the parliament. This bill is basically unnecessary. This bill is not necessary for the implementation of a voluntary work for the dole scheme. Why do I say that? Because that is the evidence that was supplied when the Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which inquired into this bill, took evidence from representatives of the minister's department, the Department of Social Security.

The government, under that evidence, could have had a voluntary work for the dole scheme running now without this bill, because essentially this bill is about the compulsion aspects of this proposal. I will quote from the government senators' report on this bill. At paragraph 3.24 on page 10, the report states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The expectation . . . in Work for the Dole projects would be largely voluntary has been clearly stated by the Government. In the pilot projects it is expected that the requirement to participate would be minimal, if at all.

SPEECH.PARA: There was evidence from Mr Powlay of the Department of Social Security confirming that the voluntary aspects of this program could be achieved under the current Social Security Act.

So why doesn't the government get voluntary schemes up and running to pilot this concept now? I think that is a matter that requires some contemplation. But I wanted to touch upon the issue of voluntary participation in these schemes, in voluntary work generally and the value of that and the effect on that of compulsion.

To do that, I want to refer to evidence which the committee took from the Australian Council for Volunteering, an organisation which coordinates various volunteer organisations which assist people to get into voluntary work. That evidence was given in Sydney. Firstly, I should say that the Australian Council for Volunteering, and the witnesses appearing for them, clearly rejected the involvement of persons compelled to participate in their schemes, feeling that their participation would undermine the work of these voluntary organisations. I want to refer to some of the evidence given by Ms Sha Cordingley and Ms Marie Fox to the Senate inquiry. In her opening statement, Ms Cordingley said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The compulsory work for the dole scheme, we believe, reinforces the negative perception of volunteering for young unemployed people. There are many young unemployed people who are taking up volunteering currently as an option in their search for paid work experience. I would like to quote from a study done in the UK. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there were mixed views about asking unemployed people to take up volunteering. No-one felt that voluntary activities should be compulsory. Indeed, most felt that any suggestion of volunteering should be separated as far as possible from the process of claiming benefit. To link the two more directly was construed as " more like a punishment " and "a bit like being on probation ," or "serving a community service order ." Unanimously, people felt that it was an issue that needed to be handled with great tact and sensitivity. Nevertheless, those people who were both unemployed and also active volunteers felt that people who were out of work could benefit greatly by getting involved.
And in answer to a question from the chair of the committee, Ms Cordingley said:

We believe that young unemployed people gain enormously from volunteer work. It is not just in terms of intangible things like self-esteem, but it is also skill related. Young unemployed people who undertake volunteer work develop work related skills. Through proper matching of young unemployed people to volunteer organisations of their choice, they can determine the skills they want to develop and the sorts of agencies they want to work in. But underpinning that, we believe that choice and the ability to say to people, `We chose to do this. We have shown initiative,' is probably the most critical thing for unemployed people doing volunteer work.

The fact that they can demonstrate to employers that they have taken the initiative to seek out work, to determine what sorts of skills they want to develop and have turned up, have developed those skills and have entered into a work relationship with an organisation is probably the most critical thing for young unemployed people.

What this witness was telling the committee, essentially, was that this bill will undermine the potential for great positives to come from a scheme like this (that is, if the scheme were voluntary) and that this scheme, its compulsory aspects in particular, will stigmatise the participants—that is, it will devalue the involvement of the volunteers, because employers will look at this scheme and say, `Well, we don't know whether you were a volunteer or whether you were there compulsorily.'

Looking at that, they will not know whether they can take from that that the person chose, of their own volition, to become involved, to develop skills, to show that they had some sort of work ethic. Sure, it is important to develop these ethics, but also are we not seeking to develop them with the purpose of making these people more job ready? If that is not a responsible and reasonable purpose of this scheme, then I do not know what is. Ms Fox, another witness from the same organisation, talking about what is possible now, said:

In a recent submission that we made to the Department of Social Security we talked about our capacity to build a skills passport, basically, or a resume of work that they have done: the times that they have spent, the fact that they have low absenteeism, that they have a work ethic and these sort of things, but they do it by choice, not by compulsion.
And, she said, later:

The ABS statistics—unfortunately, we did not bring those to table for you—on volunteering that were conducted in 1995, and the report issued in 1996, showed that the majority of volunteers in Australia at the current time are aged between 19 and 35 years of age.

In other words, the experience now was that there was not a lack of volunteering in the age group that has been targeted in this bill. This organisation had been going to the minister's department, talking about some of the possibilities for using the volunteering scheme that are currently able to be used under the social security legislation to improve aspects of skills and, perhaps, the work ethic aspects of some of the young unemployed.

There is ample evidence, according to this organisation—I do not think there was any evidence to contradict it—that young people will be volunteers, that volunteers can achieve growth in work ethic and a growth in employability for the unemployed. When we looked at the evidence that we had from this organisation, we could see that what we were faced with was a bill which essentially dealt with the negative aspects of this scheme—not the positives, not what could be achieved, but what might actually bring the aims of this proposal down. Further, in answers to questions by Senator Tierney, talking about her own experience with the long-term unemployed, Ms Cordingley said:
In my own centre, probably about a quarter of the people would be long-term unemployed, with the remainder being people who have quite recently found themselves unemployed—
talking about volunteers of course—

or are unemployed after leaving school or a university course. We could find that out for you, as a percentage, but it is not the largest percentage of people who are long-term unemployed. I think they find it more difficult to enter the volunteer work force, but that is partly because it has never really been promoted as a proper option for people either.
And later:

To promote the opportunities to volunteer through the CES offices and to work with them to offer volunteering as an option for people who are unemployed. One of the things we have found is that even with the relaxation of the DSS guidelines, or under the terms of the Social Security Act, often those at the officer level within CES are not aware that people are entitled to volunteer, or that, providing they comply with the work test, they can volunteer regardless of any government legislation.

Our plan would be to work with the CES officers to ensure that people were alerted to the fact that volunteering is a viable option for them. That is probably the only way, apart from putting vast amounts of money into advertising that volunteer work is an option. That would be our most cost‐effective way of doing it.

In other words, their proposal—which this organisation is putting to the department—is to get some sort of voluntary scheme up for unemployed people. Could it be done? Yes. Was it being done? No. We have aspects of this bill which really are negatives to the aims that the scheme is alleged to have. This bill is an open‐ended proposal for legislation and, as Senator Kernot says, it actually provides for an open‐ended scheme which is not limited to young people and could be the basis of compulsory work for unemployment benefit. In that respect this is potentially a punishment bill.

I do not think we need evidence about the scope of this bill to be used for the government's announced policy other than to refer to comments that Senator Vanstone made in relation to the Reform of Employment Services Bill where the minister is saying in effect, `If you don't pass that bill, we will use provisions of the Social Security Act to implement our policy anyway.'

If the government believes that it is good public policy to implement an unannounced policy in terms of an election campaign—and I am talking in this case about the Reform of Employment Services Bill—by using legisla tion which was introduced on an entirely different basis, then what confidence can we have that this bill will not be used to implement something more than it announces now, something quite different? Senator Kernot talked about the conflict between the executive and the parliament. This bill will remove the question of work for the dole for all from this parliament while ever the bill passes and stands in law.

That brings me to what I believe is one of very important aspects of the proposed amendments which the opposition and the Democrats propose, and that is that there be a sunset clause to this bill. If we are going to have an open‐ended piece of legislation to allow a pilot to occur, we should be in a position of being able to say that, as a matter of public policy, it should not be used for anything else until it comes back to this parliament. The government's argument against this proposal is contained in the majority government report on this bill and the only justification or argument against it was this passage on page 23:
DEETYA used the process of evaluation argument to reach a different conclusion,—
that is against the sunset clause—

advising the Committee that any decision to extend the scheme would depend upon the results of Stage 1 of the evaluation which would be considered in the 1998-99 Budget context. `Therefore, a "sunset clause" is not required' concluded DEETYA.

When the government in the context of the 1998-99 budget considers it policy in this regard, it will set policy. That is the basis for not needing a sunset clause—we will rely on the government to make the right decision. That is essentially what that decision is telling us. Really, if that is to be the sole justification that this government has against introducing a sunset clause, then it has no justification at all. Facilitating a pilot scheme is one thing—however flawed that scheme might be—opening the legislative flood gates for the implementation of more unmandated, unannounced, knee jerk policies is another. No sunset clause means opening up those flood gates.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there is only one other brief comment that I want to make about this bill, although there are many I could make if time permitted me to do so. There is significant evidence which was presented to the committee in relation to the legal obligations which would apply to sponsors of these pilot projects or other projects in the future. It is clear that, even though this bill purports to extinguish certain health and safety, workers' compensation and employee rights, the evidence states that, unless there is reciprocal legislation from state governments, that extinguishment may not be complete in total.

There is also the question, therefore, of liability for the participants. There are questions which I have asked as to the insurance covers that the sponsors are obliged to receive, whether they will be any shortfalls and who will cover them. I am concerned that we may start a pilot project which has severe and unintended consequences for well‐meaning and well‐intentioned sponsors who become involved in these projects but find down the track that their obligations are more than what they expected them to be and that they will be faced with severe financial burdens. I believe that this government will be morally obliged to bail them out, but there is no guarantee in this bill that that will occur. That is another matter for policy and another matter for us to depend upon this government to attend to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite surprising that this government seeks to enshrine in law the word `dole'. As far as I am aware this is unprecedented. That word, as many Australians know, carries with it many negative connotations, associations of idleness, of a lack of motivation and of being uncaring. The work for the dole legislation sends a message to the community, and in particular to young Australians, that young people are somehow lacking in motivation and lacking a work ethic and that they need to be compelled in order to work.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of tackling the issue of job creation and the need for additional education and training opportunities for young people, instead of acknowledging the radical and fundamental changing nature of this country's work force, this government yet again seeks to scapegoat young people, and in particular young unemployed Australians.

The government seeks to introduce a scheme that compels young people to work for social security benefits, implying that young Australians require compulsion or are, indeed, unwilling to work. It is a message that has been sent very strongly from day one of this government. It has been reinforced by aspects of the media and perpetuated by many decision makers in this parliament and in other bodies.

As for the meagre benefits that young Australians are expected to compulsorily work for, as many as 25,000 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds will lose those benefits under the common youth allowance proposals this week. Another 50,000 will face reduction in benefits and 12,000 to 13,000 will lose those benefits completely as a result of the new means testing arrangements under this week's announcement of CYA. That common youth allowance marks the latest phase in the government's targeting of young Australians. It is a pattern of targeting and hitting hardest at those least able to afford it and is part of this government's systematic attack on young Australians.

Apart from suffering through the negative images and stereotypes perpetuated by the media and some politicians, young people have had to cope with a series of legislative programs designed to strip them of what benefits they have, entrench these stereotypes and saddle young people and students in particular with increased levels of debt.

Last year, this government introduced a job seeker diary. Again, behind this scheme was a sense that young unemployed people or unemployed people generally were not trying hard enough, that if they only looked harder, looked further, looked wider they might actually have a chance of getting a job. There was an implication that unemployed people were somehow ripping off the system, that fraud was rampant. But we know that fraud within the social security system is not rampant. And how, I ask, does keeping a diary enhance one's prospects of getting a job? It seemed to have no purpose or rationale behind it other than punishing the unemployed and implying, `If only they were trying harder.'

We seem to have forgotten in this and other debates in this place that the problem is a lack of jobs. There are not enough jobs out there for young Australians, let alone the kind of sustainable and long‐term meaningful jobs that Australians, I believe, deserve. The decision to introduce the diary, just as the recent common youth allowance changes and the work for the dole scheme, fundamentally misread the economic and social reality of young people's lives today and, of course, those of their families.

When some ministers in this government were young, the levels of youth unemployment were between two and three per cent. Those levels are now between 20 and 30 per cent. The latest figures demonstrate that more than 27 per cent of 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds in Australia are looking for work. That figure is as high as 37 per cent in the home state of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. These figures are shameful, as I am sure we all agree in this place, but I see very little being done to assist with job creation in this country.

The government does not seem to understand that the youth jobs market has changed in Australia. In the mid 1960s, two‐thirds of 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds had full time jobs. Now it is less than a fifth of those. Generally, it was much easier for our parents to get jobs than it has been for today's younger generations. We have now had high levels of youth unemployment for over a decade and this has had a dramatic effect on how young people view themselves, their potential and their role in our society.

In the last decade, the number of teenagers outside full‐time education or not in full‐time jobs has gone from one in four to one in two. So young people have borne the brunt of the unemployment crisis. They have pursued high levels of education and training and more qualifications in the hope of gaining employment. They have stayed in school for longer periods than ever before. They are doing traineeships, apprenticeships, short courses, long courses, filling in diaries and applying for jobs knowing that hundreds of other young people are applying for similar jobs, and many of them are facing rejection on a daily basis.

What has the government done to fulfil its election promise, to give hope to young people? They have cut labour market programs, they have axed thousands of jobs, they have reduced access to education and training through disincentives such as additional fees and charges, they have harassed the unemployed with job seeker dairies and the employer contact unit, dubbed the `Dob in a dole bludger hotline', and now they seek to enshrine in law a work for the dole scheme which is designed to perpetuate notions that the unemployed, young unemployed in particular, require compulsion to work.

This government is about dole bludgeoning, getting them breached, making them scapegoats, compelling them to work on projects that deliver very few if any jobs at the end of it. I do not see the same attention being paid to clamping down on tax avoidance, although corporate fraud is estimated to cost the taxpayer $20 billion per annum, compared with $10 million in social security payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come off it! You cannot be serious. You are a joke. What a joke!
—Not with the same vigour, not with the same enthusiasm, not with the same appeal to the papers and the populist polls, Senator Campbell.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia we have a youth crackdown, and the media, I acknowledge, is culpable as well. Perhaps that is why some media outlets tagged onto the work for the dole bandwagon so eagerly. I remember front page pictures of young people at the beach. The indication was that life is a beach for young unemployed people with young people hanging round, smoking, looking casual, looking as though they lacked focus and motivation. Nearly ever paper in Australia carried those photographs accompanying the announcement by Dr Kemp of the proposed work for the dole program. If you are under 21, the easiest way to get into the media is to commit a crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is reinforcing the stereotypes now? You.
—But in the media, young people who are haunted, who are unable to get a job—
—You should be ashamed.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, as far as I am aware, other speakers were heard in silence. I have no intention of interjecting through the minister.
—Senator Stott Despoja, if I think interjections are getting out of hand, I will call senators to order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. In the media, young people who do not have jobs are haunted by what has become known as the Paxton phenomena, Paxton phobia, as it has been termed by Kim Davey from the Youth Affairs Council of South Australia. How well many of us remember the vilification of that particular family by a Current Affair , aided and abetted by some politicians. The information obtained through freedom of information about the Paxton's case makes very interesting reading and smacks of direct political interference. But how they were vilified and how that image of young Australians being unwilling to work has been perpetuated by shock jocks, talkback radio and many in positions of power.

BREAK.PARA: The week of the announcement of the work for the dole plan was a sad one. Apart from the general reaction of the media, I remember the front page headline in, I believe, the Australian, where the Prime Minister said to young people, `You owe us.' After all the platitudes and promises and rhetoric from the Prime Minister and the government in the lead‐up to the election—all the talking about giving hope to the young—what about those young people, their parents and their families saying to the government that perhaps it owes young people at least a shot at job opportunities.

I do not believe that anyone in this place disputes the notion that has been talked about today of mutual obligation. It is a concept that has been part of the social welfare system in this country for many years. Indeed, those people on unemployment benefits do engage in a variety of activities: activity tests, now the diaries, engaging in training and other schemes. These are all part of the process now, and usually with the blessing of most in the community. But this legislation seeks to entrench not the concept of mutual obligation but a sense that young unemployed Australians should be penalised even further for the position in which they find themselves.

I know some people in this place have a commitment to the concept of intergenerational equity, a concept the Democrats have long believed in: the notion that we have an obligation to pass on to further generations this land, this environment, this world, in at least as good shape as when we inherited it, if not in better shape.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deficits.

—Members of this government, I acknowledge, talk about getting rid of the so‐called budget black hole, the deficit, for that very reason, so that young people are not burdened with economic deficits and hardships. But what about the environmental deficits? What about the intellectual and social deficits? What about the fact that, at the same time as people seek to remove this economic burden from young people and future generations, young people are a debt generation increasingly saddled with higher debt levels? For example, in higher education the combination of paying back Austudy loans and HECS fees can be around $30,000 worth of debts that they are paying off well into the middle of their lives.

BREAK.PARA: And the government dares this week, with the common youth allowance, to claim that this is about providing incentives. I am the first to acknowledge to the minister that there are aspects of the CYA that are positive, and the Democrats have acknowledged that, whether it is the extension of rent assistance to students living away from home or whether it is the recognition of de facto relationships of two years or more for the independent status. I acknowledge those things as positive moves.

But I cannot accept that throwing 16‐ and 17‐year‐olds off unemployment benefits is positive. I cannot accept that removing the benefits that exist for those people not engaged in education or training or study of some form necessarily provides an incentive for other young people to engage in education and training. If you want to do that, you provide incentives in the form of a livable income and reasonable income supplements. You do not introduce disincentives in the form of fees and charges, HECS hikes, up‐front full cost fees and other loans. That is not the way to provide incentives. And you certainly need to provide additional education and training places. I see no recognition in this legislation, in a plan such as the work for the dole plan, of the need for fully accredited training and other skill development and training opportunities.

In my first speech I said that often it is said that some societies have a special respect for the aged and that I think our society has a fear of the young. Unfortunately, I have seen nothing since I have been in parliament and nothing from this government that suggests otherwise, in legislation or in media or in any programs or laws. John Casimir from the Sydney Morning Herald puts it quite simply. `We are demonising our youth,' he says. Everywhere I look, there are negative messages about young people being directed at young Australians.

The issue of public space and young people is indicative. Curfews and move‐on laws in public areas are specifically targeted at young Australians. One has to ask: what is a public space for? Aren't young people members of the public as well? Whether it is messages about young people and crime, young people and drug and alcohol abuse, young people and homelessness, young people as dole bludgers—all these are stereotypes designed to reinforce the idea that young people are something to be scared of and certainly not respected.

The Prime Minister and his colleagues want a relaxed and comfortable Australia, but I would suggest that there is one thing the Prime Minister is not so comfortable and relaxed about, and that is young Australians. This government has consistently introduced policies and measures that discriminate against young people, target them, victimise them and penalise them. The pall of censorship may have been lifted, according to the Prime Minister, but the reality is that the censorship and the crackdown on young people's views and expressions and opinions have just begun.

I note that this week the government has announced that in 1998 it will hold national youth week. I believe around $400,000 has been allocated to that particular project. The Democrats would commend any additional resources designed to promote young Australians, and certainly to promote positive images about young Australians, but we hope the government does not use that as some sort of marketing or PR exercise for itself.

Why not use the resources and the money and the energy to promote young people and demonstrate a real commitment to young Australians in the form of jobs, education and training opportunities and real opportunities to develop the self‐esteem we keep hearing so much about? Instead, young people have been denied livable incomes and income supplements. They have been denied adequate education and training opportunities, and the basic principles of freedom and respect and non‐discrimination.

Young Australians require real jobs. We should be planning now to provide real, sustainable, long‐term, satisfying, meaningful jobs for young Australians. That means not short‐term courses or compulsory work for the dole schemes; it means governments investing in the industries and the businesses of the future. It means being a little gutsy and looking beyond the next election cycle or cycles and investing in high‐tech fields and value‐added manufacturing. It means looking at how we can fix the environment so that we can create jobs at the same time—not Macjobs, not low value, low skill, undervalued and underpaid positions for young Australians. We want jobs for the future. If the government wants to give young people hope, as it promised in its election paraphernalia and propaganda, try jobs, because that will lead to giving young Australians the self- esteem that apparently you so desire them to have. The minister and her colleagues owe young people that much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this important debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill 1997. I find it somewhat surprising how many people can see amendments to legislation in such different lights. Quite clearly, this government does not set about to punish young people with this measure. It is quite the contrary; we are trying to give young people an extra go—a fairer go—than life has dealt them so far. We are not about bastardising young people. That is probably not parliamentary; I am not quite sure what the alternative word is.

SPEECH.PARA: There are about 10,000 young people who will be helped through the legislation this year if the Senate does pass this legislation. There are many long-term unemployed young people who have become terribly isolated from their community who would benefit greatly from working on some worthwhile community project at the same time as making contact with people who are going to help them get a job, perhaps at the end of the project. Surely that is a noble endeavour.

We are talking about those young people who are having the greatest difficulty finding work, to the extent that a lot of us realise that a percentage of them have given up hope, lost confidence in themselves and have trudged the streets looking for work for so long that they have given it away. Surely we should as a nation be striving our utmost for those young people. I cannot believe that we are talking about the same program when we hear Senator Stott Despoja just now with her claims about how the government sees young people. We are parents and we are grandparents and we certainly understand that life has dealt some of these young people a pretty rotten hand and it is up to us to do something about it.

Work for the dole is by no means the only measure that will do something for these young people. It is but a small element of it. It is a pilot program and it is amongst a number of other programs which will help young people. Some of them are short term, like this, and some of them are medium term, like the youth allowance and the marvellous new scheme that Dr Kemp has introduced for new apprenticeships and traineeships. Some of them, sadly, are more long term. By that I mean the measures which this government has already taken to try to get the nation's accounts into the black. Without that effort, which has been painful for so many people, we would never have investment confidence in this country. If we do not have investment confidence, those jobs will not flow to young people.

On every hand, this government is taking measures which will lead to jobs for young people who have been so sadly disadvantaged over the last few years. We have never claimed that work for the dole is there to create real jobs. Our policies to bring down interest rates, to revive small business, to reform industrial relations and to produce apprenticeships and traineeships will be creating real jobs, not mirage jobs financed by debt. If Senator Stott Despoja thinks that mirage jobs financed by debt are the way ahead, we have a different view of the long-term needs of this country.

Work for the dole will help the most disadvantaged group in the labour market come back out of their isolation and revive their self‐esteem so that they really are much more able to get the jobs that are available. The vast majority of young people taking part in this scheme will be volunteers. They will see that these projects are worth while and they will want to take part in them. It is fascinating that some of the keenest proponents of the scheme are young people.

Compulsion has been criticised. We believe that compulsion is fair. One of the reasons we believe that is that there are some young people who have become so isolated in their long-term unemployment that they are most unlikely to come out of that isolation without more than just an offer of a voluntary work for the dole program. They will need the encouragement to join those who perhaps still have more confidence. I think that it is important that they have the ability to be encouraged into the scheme through the compulsory nature of some of the pilots so they also come out of it feeling that they have put something back into the community.

There are 70 pilot schemes planned. We have had tremendous reaction from around the country, particularly from the voluntary organisations in regional Australia because they see at first hand what a waste of young lives unemployment brings. There is a great enthusiasm and willingness to have some worthwhile projects that will not only help that community but will help unemployed young people and will also help the learning process, because they are pilot projects, as to how best we can help the long-term unemployed young people in the future. The pilot nature of the program is very important.

Senator Kernot mentioned the UK options of work for welfare. It was very interesting that she should do so. I am advised by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs that we are leaders in Australia in terms of the measures that we are putting in place for unemployment. The four measures that the United Kingdom is working on are subsidised jobs, voluntary work, environmental work and provision of skills for the unskilled. We have had subsidised jobs for quite a while under the previous government, and they are still continuing until March next year. But that money will then be cashed out to be spent on intervention in a more focused way appropriate to each individual rather than a broad brush approach. That help will go to each individual as it is needed.

Voluntary work has already been acknowledged by this government to be a vitally important component of helping people back into the paid work force, and a number of measures which we passed in our first budget go to assisting people get into voluntary employment, as part of satisfying the activity test. The Green Corps is another project which helps young people who are unemployed and those who are not. It is still a pilot project, but it is another element that tries to help young people get on their feet.

BREAK.PARA: Finally there is developing skills for the unskilled. The youth allowance reforms are important for a variety of reasons. One of the most important has to be helping young people to acquire the skills that they currently do not have, which is why they therefore cannot get jobs. I hope that we are world leaders in Australia. If Senator Kernot says that work for welfare in the United Kingdom is the way we should be going, she should take a very close look at home because it is the way we have already gone.

I have commented on people who claim that we are out to punish the unemployed. Senator Kernot said it; Senator Brown said it; Senator Stott Despoja said it. It is nonsense and I utterly reject it. Senator Brown said that we needed positive outcomes. Of course we need positive outcomes. That is what we are on about. That is what it is for. He is talking about how you come into the scheme; we talk about how you come out of the scheme.

Renewed confidence, self-esteem, satisfaction from having contributed to a job that needed doing in your community and contacts with helpful people are surely the outcomes we would be wanting for these disadvantaged young people. He said that we are perverse, that we are discriminatory, that we are heartless and that it is the rich hitting the poor. The government utterly rejects that nonsense. It is monstrous.

We believe that traineeships, apprenticeships and vocational education generally are the preferable pathway to jobs. Work for the dole will provide a very valuable experience for young people that they currently do not have available to them.

Senator Mackay was talking about some matters which I think she was pretty inaccurate about, and I would like to correct the record. The department will be taking out insurance to cover participants. The sponsors will be responsible for safety equipment, for clothes for public contact, for training on safety aspects where necessary and for maintaining a secure workplace. Also, private businesses will not be able to be sponsors. Therefore, Senator Mackay's talk of payroll tax is an irrelevance. I know that Senator O'Brien was on the committee and knows that these things were inaccurate, but he did not say that. It is a shame that Senator Mackay came ill‐prepared to the debate.

She also talked about the need to implement a sensible training program. As I flagged briefly before, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, is putting that program in place right now. The national portable recognition of apprenticeships and traineeships is under way. The provision of MAATS and the extra places in TAFE are all sensible training programs which already are available to young people and will make the difference. Work for the dole has a different purpose. The training necessary to do the job on the work for the dole scheme will be provided where it is required. It is for the recovery of self‐confidence. It is not a training scheme; it is not a scheme to provide work of itself.

I briefly mention the claim that was made by Senator Margetts about our international obligations. The government has taken the advice of the Attorney-General's Department that the work for the dole initiative should not contravene our international obligations provided the work offered is `suitable and reasonable for that person'. The advice read:

The fact that payment of unemployment allowance is not based on any prior mandatory contribution, combined with the positive benefits of work for the dole for participants, means that the initiative should be regarded as reasonable in its requirement of a contribution to the community from participants. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has advised the Senate committee on this bill that it will confirm that the final design of the program does not breach any international obligations.

Senator O'Brien, who I thought gave us a very thoughtful speech, recognised the value of voluntary work. I have already mentioned the reforms in the Social Security Act in that area. We do not believe that the fact that there will be some element of compulsion in some pilots will devalue the work of the volunteer. It is not in what capacity they go into the scheme; it is in what manner they are able to come out of it—it is pride and achievement that really count.

The need to evaluate this program is also important. The committee inquiring into the work for the dole scheme was advised by the department of the evaluation process, which is proposed to be in two parts—half will be in time for the budget next year and the other half will be done late next year. It is intended that that will be a transparent system of evaluation; certainly, the reports will be available publicly.

We believe that it is very important that we all understand what we have achieved with this program. As there will be so many pilots of such variety, and they will be depending very much on the local needs in each of the regional areas, then it is important that we study what worked, what did not work and what was average. There will be good, better and best, and there might be some poor and not good at all. That is the way we will learn about how this can be advanced in the future.

There has been talk of a sunset clause. Nobody is going to want to continue a program if it does not work. Clearly, if this works—we believe it will—people will want to continue it. We do not believe that a sunset clause is an appropriate way to go.

(5) A decision to approve a program of work for unemployment payment made by the Employment Secretary under subsection (1) is a decision to approve a labour market program for the purposes of subsections 1239(2), 1240(2) and 1250(1).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 5 imposes restraints on the employment secretary's power to approve work for the dole programs. Amendment 6 provides that, if work for the dole programs effectively turn into labour market programs by meeting the conditions inserted by the previous amendment, a work for the dole program is taken to be a labour market program for the purposes of the activity test and newstart activity agreements. So the secretary can compel a person to participate in a work for the dole program under existing subsection 601(2) and 606(1). It also provides that the decision to approve a work for the dole program is taken to be a decision to approve a labour market program. Of course, such decisions are not appealable internally or to the SSAT under subsections 1239(2), 1240(2) and 1250(1) of the act.

Speaking to these amendments, which I will do for just a brief time, we in the Labor Party say that work for the dole flies in the face of a period of reform which was, until the mid-1980s, a passive labour market assistance program in Australia. The system was introduced in 1945. Unemployment was then regarded as something of a short-term problem. It was only in the mid-1980s that the Australian community decided that we had to reform the system of labour market assistance in Australia to turn it from a passive system into one that was based on an active approach to try to get people back to work.

BREAK.PARA: That, in turn, meant the government identifying and meeting its obligation to the unemployed by offering programs tailored to the special needs of particular sections of the unemployed. It was an approach that was based on what was known as a reciprocal obligation. Yes, there was compulsion but, in return for that compulsory requirement to front up to one's responsibilities, there was an investment by government to try to get those people job ready and back to work.

Since coming to power, this government has progressively dismantled the comprehensive labour market programs of the former Labor administration. It seeks to put in place of those programs a totally inadequate response, in our view, to a very pressing problem.

Labor in government instituted a raft of labour market programs which attempted, we believe, in a very real way to come to terms with the needs of the unemployed. When Mr Howard came to power, he inherited an economy where inflation had been beaten, growth exceeded four per cent and job creation ran at an unprecedented rate. Yet in his first budget and then again in his second budget a few months ago, the Prime Minister literally threw in the towel on the issue of unemployment. His government was quick to set a target for reducing the paper load for business, but it has steadfastly refused to set a target for reductions in unemployment.

These amendments that are before the committee seek to include a number of restraints on the secretary's power to approve a program of work for unemployment payment. The amendments essentially turn this into a decent labour market program. We will be seeking to require that the secretary cannot approve a program unless he or she is satisfied that the program does not displace existing workers and that it pays people for the hours of work at the relevant award rate; provides people with accredited training; allows people to take leave for education, training and employment opportunities with out penalty; funds the people running the program to cover costs associated with supervision, materials, workers compensation, essential clothing, equipment and so on; and runs for at least six months, as has been promised.

If these conditions can be satisfied, it is our view that these programs can be defined as proper labour market programs with all that that currently entails. It is reasonable to make it compulsory for people to participate in a labour market program. Indeed, under Labor, people were compelled to participate in labour market programs.

Like the government, we do not want to see what the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) has described as short‐term merry‐go‐round programs. We agree with that. There is nothing in this bill at the moment that would prevent this scheme being exactly that—a short‐term, merry‐go‐round program. I ask Senator Newman how she can suggest that this bill is going to stop the short-term merry‐go‐round, when there are no restrictions in the bill as proposed by the government—none at all—on how long the program should operate.

All of Australia saw the minister for schools on that Wednesday night ABC program. He was fronting up to the battlers of Mount Druitt and trying to explain the scheme. I do not think he is going to go back, even if he is invited. As soon as the minister had to talk to ordinary, Australian workers in western Sydney about work for the dole he was lost—hopelessly lost. They wanted training and opportunities and the sort of program reflected in the Labor Party amendments, not something that is defeatist and narrow. They wanted lifetime opportunities, and the minister could not deliver in a public presentation that was, frankly, not only totally humiliating for the minister himself; it was totally humiliating for the nature of the scheme that he has proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to outline the very positive future of Planet Earth 2000, Australia's international garden festival. This project is linked to tourism potential of the Sydney Olympics at the turn of millennium celebrations. It will be staged at picturesque Mount Penang near Gosford for six months from August 2000 to February 2001.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a great event for Australia and for the central coast. The private sector will invest over $230 million in the coming three years. Over 20 million trees, grasses, shrubs and flowers will be planted on the site. In excess of 40 nations will build international gardens with national themes. A 10,000‐seat sporting facility will be one of facilities left for the community after the festival finishes. The project will generate 18,000 full‐time equivalent jobs on the central coast and add $1.5 billion to the New South Wales economy. It is expect to attract five and half million visitors to the Planet Earth 2000 exhibition.

Given this very hopeful future and what this project can do for the central coast of the New South Wales, it is a great pity that New South Wales Labor senator, Belinda Neal, has fallen into the trap of recently making cheap political points about the future of the international garden festival. I refer to her brochure—which I have here—entitled `Garden festival alive after Howard government fails to support', which was widely distributed on the central coast. Senator Neal is in serious error when she makes the outrageous claim that:

The Howard Government jeopardised our International Garden Festival and the 18,000 jobs it would have generated when it backed away from pledges to lodge the necessary application for international status with the BIE.

The reality is that the festival has a very positive outlook and Senator Neal should stop talking it down. The Acting Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, authorised the payment of the full BIE of $180,000 on 14 April 1997. The Carr government failed to honour its back to back underwriting of the $230 million project with the private sector developer, Thiess, causing a reclassification downwards of the garden festival.

Despite the Carr government's lack of action at the crucial time of BIE lodgment, the reclassified international garden festival remains alive with final private sector and New South Wales government guarantees about to be finalised. The Howard government stands ready to provide an appropriate Commonwealth contribution consistent with our national responsibilities for such events, as indicated by a letter from the Prime Minister.

Jim Lloyd the member for Robertson and I, along with parliamentary colleagues Chris Hartcher and Mike Gallagher, will actively support the application of the funds for the Australian pavilion; real support and not just political stunts like Senator Neal's outrageous flier. Senator Neal has made outrageous false claims about the future of Planet Earth 2000 and has placed in jeopardy the future of this festival by such action. Senator Neal has sent out false signals about its viability and this is all done, of course, to support her future political aspirations for the seat of Robertson.

The adjournment debate gives me the chance to comprehensively rebut her cheap political shots by referring to the long history of problems created by Labor since the start of this project. Let me emphasise that it has been a very long struggle to generate both state and federal government support and private sector underwriting over a period of five years. The project has required from time to time bipartisan support from all MPs, state and federal, Liberal and Labor, to try and generate the support the garden festival deserves.

The record of all governments over time, including the Keating and Carr governments, has been patchy. The garden has had to fight to survive the scepticism of various ministers and bureaucrats at the state and federal level. Local ALP federal member Michael Lee in Dobell and Frank Walker in Robertson, the local federal seats, refused to support the event in 1994-95 when valuable years of planning were lost. Michael Lee and Frank Walker, as members of the Keating cabinet, failed to use their authority to support a major project on the central coast. Michael Lee as tourism minister was especially negligent in not supporting this great project when he had the ministerial authority to do so.

In the dying days of the Keating government there was a promise of $12 million of Working Nation money, but of course this never materialised. For Senator Neal's benefit the actual sum spent by the Keating Labor government on this project was a grand total of $20,000, being the 10 per cent deposit to the BIE. Meanwhile the Carr Labor government in New South Wales has had a very patchy record on this issue. Following their election win in March 1995, it took the new Treasurer, Michael Egan, just one month to entirely withdraw support from the international garden festival. In 1996 they had finally changed their mind again and joined with Prime Minister, John Howard, to fund $300,000 from each government to encourage the seed funding needed from the private sector.

The New South Wales government then committed the juvenile justice land at Mount Penang valued at $17.3 million in the Treasury papers—not the $25 million as claimed by Senator Neal in her recent election mailout. The state Liberal government of John Fahey is the only government with an impeccable record in support of the project. Premier Fahey approved $1 million in 1994 for the feasibility study and site selection. The Fahey government was committed to this project and, if it had been returned to office, there would have been a much smoother run for this festival.

From this point on, securing the festival future is vital and there are four elements to this. The International Horticultural Organisation has approved a reclassified festival with the full support of the Nursery Industry Association of Australia. The reclassified festival has two private sector bidders finalising underwriting and contracts of $230 million for this event. The New South Wales government has confirmed that the land, conditional upon the whole project being underwritten and guaranteed by the private sector at Mount Penang, will be gifted to the festival trust. Jim Lloyd and I will be working through the process of the application for funds for the Australian pavilion from the federal government.

I urge Senator Neal to return to the bipartisan approach which used to exist and work with Jim Lloyd and I to help secure this vital investment for the Central Coast. If Senator Neal comes back to a sense of bipartisanship, we may actually achieve the one true statement in her brochure which was that the festival will jump start the local economy, bring 18,000 jobs and leave a world‐class recreational facility for the community. For the central coast, I urge Senator Neal to drop the politics and use her position to secure the outcome that we all support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to speak on the issue of cooked chicken meat and its entry into Australia. Last week in the state of Queensland, particularly in the Redland shire, there was a meeting of some 300 people interested in this issue who attended to hear a keynote speaker from the Australian Institute, Dr Clive Hamilton. Dr Hamilton had given out a flier which said that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government's obsession with trade has blinded them to the implications of relaxing quarantine regulations.

It was in that environment that this meeting was first called. The Redland shire is one of the fastest growing areas of Australia and covers the federal seats of Bowman and Fadden. The meeting was part of a national campaign by the chicken industry to protest about the proposed federal government decision to allow the importation of chicken meat into Australia. There was an array of speakers and observers at the meeting, including in a very bipartisan group of speakers from all political parties. Senator John Woodley was there; the federal member for Bowman Andrea West was there; the state member for Redland John Hegarty, who is a National Party member; was there, the federal shadow minister for primary industries Neil O'Keefe was there; a member of my staff was there on my behalf as an observer; the mayor of Redland shire Eddie Santaguiliana was there; and last but not least was the state opposition leader Peter Beattie. So it covered the whole spectrum of politics.

The meeting not only represented people from the production side of chicken meat in that area but also from the consumer side as well. All speakers soundly condemned the action of the government at that particular meeting. Whilst the member for Bowman did not address the meeting, in a subsequent speech in the House of Representatives on 16 June the member for Bowman did clearly register opposition to the pending action of the government.

The main reason that people are speaking out so forcefully is that there are three major risks. The first is the risk to our native birds because, as the flier from the opponents of this say, the greatest threat to indigenous wildlife in Australia would come from the introduction of Newcastle disease, and that is the problem that is being faced with the cooked chicken meat. Secondly, our health and safety is at risk. A report from ANZFA has classified imported cooked chicken meat as a high risk food. Thirdly, there is a risk to jobs and whilst Australian chicken growers focus on jobs throughout Australia where they claim that approximately 40,000 people depend on the chicken industry for a living, in the Redland shire a large number of people are dependent upon this industry for their lifestyle.

So there are three major focuses as to why this meeting was so well attended and was so much in condemnation of the action that this government is taking. In particular, if you look at the native wildlife, they are going to be exposed to a disease which is, as I understand it, quite virulent and will go through the wildlife and cause some havoc and devastation with our native species.

In particular at that meeting the mayor Eddie Santaguilana said that the disease would not only harm bird wildlife but that the disease will also destroy our poultry industry, bankrupt farmers and put thousands of people out of work. It is very difficult to prioritise which of those risks is the greatest risk.

Briefly I would like to look at the risk to jobs because in the Redland shire the production of chicken meat is responsible for the 10 million to 13 million birds per year being produced from 24 farms. So it is not an insignificant industry at all and there is an overall turnover of some $20 million.

Each farm invariably is run by two people on average and there is a multiplier effect which is four to five times that number into other areas of industry and the community. This includes people such as catchers, transport, people in feed milling and processing.

If one considers those 24 farms alone, there are a substantial number of people involved in and dependent on this industry. However, when one looks further, one finds that not only are there about 300 jobs on those farms but that the major operations have not been accounted for in those earlier figures. I particularly refer to the operation by Darwalla, where over 100 people are directly involved and there are countless people involved indirectly. So one can start to see the magnitude of the problem that is faced in the Redland shire, where this industry is such an important employer and such a generator of income and business for the community.

The meeting roundly condemned what the government is proposing in terms of the cooked chicken meat industry and exhorted the government not to proceed down the path of allowing cooked chicken meat into this nation. In particular, the chicken industry has put forward a five‐point plan. I will run through those points because I believe that they deserve strong consideration. They read:
1. That a full technical evaluation of the capabilities of commercial cooking ovens and monitoring and control equipment suitable for quarantine control be conducted;

2. That suitably qualified Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service staff and industry technologists (by invitation) inspect all applicant processing facilities in the USA and Denmark as has recently been conducted in Thailand;
3. That source chickens for import to Australia as cooked chicken meat come only from regions certified free of diseases of greatest quarantine/economic significance;
4. That the areas of disagreement between AQIS and the industry concerning matters of detail contained in the draft protocols be further examined; and
5. That the protocols be framed in a manner that requires less subjective judgment by AQIS staff.

It is on those five points that the industry are proposing to protect not only the wildlife of Australia, our native birds, but also our health and our safety. We should also not put jobs at risk unnecessarily when jobs are the number one factor we should be looking at in this nation.
The meeting really got to the heart of the community, was supported by the community and roundly condemned the moves by this government to allow chicken meat to be imported into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to take this opportunity to talk on the issues that affect my electorate, specifically with regard to the developments in uranium mining. We are all very well aware in the Senate that there was a recent report by the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling and that that report was tabled during May 1997 and is currently up for consideration by the Senate in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to commend the report for many of the actions that it canvassed, for many of the issues that it addressed and for many of the recommendations and conclusions that have been drawn. In particular, I have been very pleased at the involvement of two of my colleagues, Senator Grant Chapman and Senator Alan Ferguson—both South Australians, I should mention, and with their own interest in Roxby Downs. I have no doubt that they had sympathy for many of the issues that were canvassed.

It is also important to note a very major shift by the Australian Labor Party on the issues of uranium policy that actually were reflected in this particular report. I am pleased to note and to acknowledge that Senator Mark Bishop and Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds have both agreed with the report, and in fact many of the recommendations that have come into play as a result of this report.

I think it signals to this industry and to the Australian people that the issues can with time be canvassed and addressed. I am pleased to note and acknowledge that the Australian Labor Party is at last seeing commonsense with regard to the ridiculous policy that was imposed for so many years with the three‐mines policy. Another position may well now be able to be adopted with much more openness by the Australian Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to acknowledge that the committee report itself has drawn this conclusion:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.
The report also says:

On the basis of available evidence, the uranium mining and milling industry will be sufficiently viable financially to be able to meet its environmental, health and safety, and security responsibilities fully.

This is important because the issues that were being addressed in the Northern Territory—and I am aware that they are under consideration by the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill—with regard to EISs that are currently before the government over the development of Jabiluka and also the review of the activities at Ranger and Jabiru are most important.

Ranger's environmental performance has been acknowledged to be very significant and a credit to them. It is acknowledged that there has been no deleterious effect on the local river system from activities at Ranger. The Ranger tailings storage system has operated satisfactorily in containing the tailings and it has caused no environmental degradation. Seepage from the tailings dam was overestimated by the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry—that is, the Fox inquiry—as were the transport of heavy metals in groundwater and the environmentally vitiating effects of seepage. No environmental effects are observable.

The Fox commission's concerns over the potential for damage caused by blasting have proved to be unfounded. A management regime was able to be developed to allow performance well within the expectations outlined by the RUEI. The negative effects on the environment by both sulfur dioxide and radon were overestimated by the Fox commission. These pollutants are effectively undetectable in the broader environment.

The report also draws to our attention the fact that the Ranger mine is widely regarded as the most regulated mine in the world. This observation is especially true of the supervision and monitoring of Ranger's impacts on the environment.

Ranger has been an important contribution to the Northern Territory economy. We need to look back at the construction cost in 1980 dollars of some $326 million. A further $62 million was spent on the construction of the township of Jabiru. ERA paid, in 1980 dollars again, $407 million to the government for the government's right to the uranium resource. Since 1980 ERA has generated more than $2.8 billion in sales revenue.

Until June 1985—June 1985, I stress—Ranger contributed $198 million in wages, $27 million as an export levy to fund the Office of Supervising Scientist, $119 million in Commonwealth royalties earmarked specifically for distribution to Aboriginal communities, $35 million in royalties to the Northern Territory and $562 million in tax. In 1995-96 the mine employed about 215 people. An amount of $639 million has been distributed in dividends to Australian shareholders from a net profit of $687 million. Probably most significantly, the 1993 ACIL economics and policy group assessed Ranger's contribution to the Australian economy as $5.3 billion. That was recorded in 1992 dollars.

So it is important that as we look at this industry we consider their occupational health and safety record. Again, the conclusions of the report were very graphic in that respect and, again, very commendable.

The social impact on the Northern Territory is important, not just because of a new township and a new development but also because of the wide variety of employment for Aborigines within the region. It is certainly acknowledged that there are and have been and will be increased employment opportunities. Aboriginal unemployment is discussed in the report, with many negative reasons given for this, which sometimes are not properly canvassed. It is interesting to note the challenges that have been picked up.

The establishment of the township of Jabiru goes much broader than servicing the mine itself. It services an important environmental resource to Australia and also a very significant tourism sector concentrated on the Kakadu National Park and in increasing Aboriginal access to amenities and services in that particular area of Arnhem Land.

What has been the impact of royalties? Again, these are very significant and generally through the provisions made through the Gagudju Association to their various members in the region. These include housing, construction and maintenance, the generators for power and water, carpentry, plumbing, mechanical and electrical services, health and education, cleaning services, garbage collection, the provision of food, including livestock, medical services, including the employment of a general practitioner and a health worker, construction and running of a school, employment of teaching staff and related services and transport. Coming out of this area there has been the construction and maintenance of roads, access to out‐stations, the provision of community vehicles for Aboriginal people and the provision of helicopters for use in the wet. This is very often not recognised due this to inaccessibility.

I mentioned earlier the provision of employment and training opportunities for Aboriginal people in the region. Of course there is a direct income—a distribution of approximately $2,000 per member of the Gagudju Association per annum. Children upon majority are entitled to approximately $23,000 that is held in trust for them. The Gagudju Association stated in its submission to the inquiry that they remain:

. . . dependent upon the royalty equivalent income from Ranger Uranium Mine for the provision of the above services. Without the assurance of payment of royalty equivalent income, Gagudju may be forced to withdraw from the provision of those services.

I am disappointed to learn that are other Aboriginal people who reside in the area—largely those associated with the Gundjemi Association—who now seem to want to torpedo the development of the Jabiluka resource that is associated with the area. That would be a pity. It would be very significant for the members of that association and for Aboriginal people in the area generally as well as for other territorians.

There are so many flow‐on and associated benefits that come from these operations. With the government's abandonment of Labor's hypocritical and absurd three‐mines policy, we will see the development of further uranium deposits in the Northern Territory. Energy Resources of Australia is currently seeking approval to proceed with a mine at Jabiluka in the territory. There are also several other deposits of uranium in the Northern
Territory and they are now workable thanks to these sorts of initiatives.

The report of the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling in Australia shows conclusively that uranium mining is not only economically viable but is also extremely safe with the very high standards of safety practised and enforced in Australia.
